That the authority having jurisdiction over such park, parkway, or recreational ground may, by permit or authorization first had or obtained or by regulation duly posted in the area affected, extend to a later hour the nighttime closing hour with respect to particular area, or parks, parkways or recreational grounds, and with respect to particular recreational activities in such parks, parkways or areas; and 
B.  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent or make unlawful the conduct of or attendance at duly authorized nighttime athletic events or activity in areas set aside and lighted for such events or activities by or with the permission of the authority having jurisdiction of such park, parkway or recreational ground; 
C.  That this section shall not apply to town-operated overnight campgrounds as described in Section 12.16.080. 
(Ord. 321 § 7-7, 1981) 
12.16.080 - Overnight camping facilities. 
    Individuals who wish to use municipal campground facilities for overnight or short duration camping shall be subject to the following provisions: 
A.  Such facilities are designed for use by mobile homes, travel trailers, truck campers and tenting equipment, and may be used by individuals for a maximum of forty-eight (48) hours without charge, after which the campground is to be vacated by the individual; 
B.  Individuals using such facilities shall be subject to all regulations duly posted concerning affected areas; 
C.  It is unlawful to violate the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 321 § 7-8, 1981) 
Chapter 12.18 - RESERVED[1] 
    All vacations of right-of-way shall comply with the requirements of section 3.13 of the Unified Land Development Code. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 967, § 34, adopted August 10, 2015 , repealed ch. 12.18, §§ 12.18.010-12.18.050, in its entirety; and set out provisions which read as set out herein. Former ch. 12.18 pertained to "Vacation of Streets and Alleys," and was derived from Ord. 536 (part), adopted 1994. 

Chapter 12.20 - TREES AND SHRUBS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Prior history: Prior code Section 29-2. 

12.20.010 - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote and protect the safety of persons and property by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees, shrubs, and other plants within the city. 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000: prior code § 29-1) 
12.20.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Park trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks. 
    "Parkway" means the area between the sidewalk and the curb that may include trees and other vegetation. The parkway is the property of the city and responsibility of maintenance and care of the parkway lies with the property owner/resident. 
    "Street trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or rights-of-way with the city. 
    "Topping" means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the crown of the tree to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000) 
12.20.030 - Parks/recreation/cemetery division. 
A.  Duties and Responsibilities. The parks/recreation/cemetery division of the public works department shall be responsible for the development and administration of a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas, and to prepare an annual update of said plan for presentation to the city council for their acceptance and approval. The approved plan shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The division, when requested by the city council, shall report, and/or make recommendations on any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work. 
B.  Operation. The parks/recreation/cemetery division operates within the guidelines for all employees as set forth in the city human resources policies and procedures and the city health and safety policy. The city administrator and the public works director shall serve in an advisory capacity to the parks/recreation/cemetery division as it relates to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000) 
12.20.040 - Street tree specifications. 
A.  The planting of street trees shall comply with the specifications found in Section 5.5.3 of the Unified Land Development Code. 
B.  Plantings Outside Property Lines. 
1.  No trees or shrubs shall be planted, grown, cultivated, maintained or permitted to be in, or on, that portion of any intersection which lies within the right angle formed by the projection of two (2) corner property lines. 
2.  No hedges or similar plantings exceeding three (3) feet in height shall be permitted between the property line and the nearest street or curb line at any point within twenty (20) feet of the street or curb line of the intersecting street. 
3.  In all districts specified for the installation of a sidewalk adjacent to the curb, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, no trees or shrubs shall be planted at a distance less than five and one-half (51/2) feet of the nearest curb or street line. 
4.  In all areas where the sidewalk is not adjacent to the curb, the planting of any trees or shrubs outside of the property line shall be in accordance with the regulations of the parks/recreation/cemetery division of the public works department. 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000) 
( Ord. No. 967, § 35, 8-10-2015 ) 
12.20.050 - Maintenance. 
A.  The parks/recreation/cemetery division shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, parks and other public property, as may be necessary to insure public safety, to minimize the potential for damage to vehicles and equipment, or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public property. The parks/recreation/cemetery division may cause or order to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewer lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is infected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
    This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with Section 12.20.040. 
B.  Tree Topping. It is unlawful as a normal practice for the parks/recreation/cemetery division or any other person or firm, to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees located under obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this chapter at the determination of the parks/recreation/cemetery division. 
C.  Pruning, Corner Clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of any sidewalk and fourteen (14) feet above the surface of any street or alley. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The parks/recreation/cemetery division shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
D.  Dead or Diseased Tree Removal on Private Property. 
1.  Declaring a Nuisance. The parks/recreation/cemetery division shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease that constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city by declaring said trees a nuisance. 
2.  Notice to Abate. The parks/recreation/cemetery division will provide the appropriate written notice to owners to abate such trees at their own expense within sixty (60) days after the date the notice is served. 
3.  Abatement by City. In the event owners fail to comply with the provisions of the notice to abate, the city shall have the authority to take such action as necessary to remove such trees. The cost of removal shall be assessed against the property, which constitutes a lien against the property. 
E.  Removal of Stumps. All stumps of street trees and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
F.  Replacement of Mature Trees. In the event of development that may infringe upon mature trees, the following considerations are to be implemented: 
1.  The City Arborist shall review the plans for all developments proposed through the community development department. The purpose of their review will be to determine whether or not there are existing trees that may be affected by such development. They will determine the approximate age of such tree(s), the historic significance of such tree(s), the approximate monetary value of such tree(s), and provide a recommendation on whether or not the development needs to be modified to avoid removal of such tree(s). If no City Arborist exists then the City shall contact a representative of the State Forestry Office who shall perform the same functions as stated within this section. 
2.  If it is determined that any tree(s) will need to be removed, the developer shall contribute funding to the city's tree planting budget in an amount equal to the value of the tree(s) to be removed as determined by the City Arborist, using established tree valuation calculations but not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per tree. This amount shall be earmarked for tree replacement along public rights-of-way. In the absence of a City Arborist, a State Forestry arborist will be contacted to determine the value. 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000: Ord. 417 (part), 1984: prior code § 29-3) 
( Ord. No. 977, § 12, 4-26-2016 ) 
12.20.060 - Compliance with chapter-Enforcement. 
A.  Interference with Parks/Recreation/Cemetery Division. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the parks/recreation/cemetery division, or any of its agents, while engaging in the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees, or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. 
B.  Licensing. It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street trees or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring the appropriate contractor's license in accordance with the provisions in Chapter 5.36 of the Douglas Municipal Code. However, no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, the applicant shall provide proof of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage, indemnifying the city from any person injured or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. 
C.  Review by City Council. The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the parks/recreation/cemetery division. Any person may appeal any ruling or order of the parks/recreation/cemetery division to the city council, who may hear the matter and make final decision. 
D.  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 629 (part), 2000: Ord. 417 (part), 1984: prior code § 29-4) 
Chapter 12.24 - MUNICIPAL CEMETERIES 

12.24.010 - Burial in cemetery required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to be buried at any place within the city limits of the city, other than in a lawfully established cemetery. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.020 - Cemetery names designated. 
    The names of the cemeteries owned by the city shall be "Douglas Park Cemetery" located within the city, and "Pioneer Cemetery" located north of the city and shall be referred to in this chapter as Douglas municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "City administrator" means the city administrator or his or her duly authorized designee. 
    "Nonresident" means an individual, group, corporation or organization who does not reside within Converse County. 
    "Resident" means an individual, group, corporation or organization who resides within Converse County. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.040 - Duties of the city administrator. 
A.  The city administrator shall establish rules and regulations within the limitations of this chapter for the management, operation and maintenance of the Douglas municipal cemeteries. Such rules will be filed in the office of the city clerk and at the cemetery office upon adoption, by resolution, by the city council. 
B.  The city administrator shall manage, operate and maintain the Douglas municipal cemeteries and see that no space in the municipal cemeteries is used or occupied in violation of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated under this chapter. 
C.  The city administrator shall be charged with the duty of collecting all moneys due and payable to the city for the purchase of any section, block, lot or space in Douglas municipal cemeteries, and any other fees due and payable for burials or other services. 
D.  The city administrator shall authorize all burial permits in Douglas municipal cemeteries and shall ensure that graves are opened and excavated in the proper section, block, lot and space. 
E.  The city administrator shall maintain records showing: (1) when and to whom the sections, lots and spaces are sold; (2) the purchase price; (3) to whom a burial permit is issued; and (4) such other information as shall be deemed advisable by the city council. 
F.  The city administrator will permit no burial within the boundaries of the historic grave sites within the Pioneer Cemetery. Platted areas of the Pioneer Cemetery outside the historic grave sites may be used for burial if the city administrator finds that all of the expansion area in the Douglas Park Cemetery has been exhausted. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.050 - Issuance of deeds. 
A.  No deed for any section, lot, block or space in Douglas municipal cemeteries will be issued and no title for same shall pass until all purchase charges payable to the city have been paid. All deeds will be issued by the city clerk, signed by the mayor and city clerk, under the seal of the city. 
B.  At the time a section, lot, block or space is purchased, the city administrator or his/her designee, may permit the purchaser to execute a promissory note for the city's charges to become due and payable on the last day of the next succeeding month without interest. 
C.  Delinquent notes shall bear interest at the maximum legal rate and no further credit shall be extended to the maker of any note which has not been paid within six (6) months from the date of execution. At the end of the six (6) months, if all fees are not paid, the city shall reclaim all spaces and may retain payments made for such spaces. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.060 - Purchase price per space. 
    The city shall charge and receive payment for services provided as set forth in this section. 
1. Infant section $100.00 2. Residents of Converse County $200.00 3. Non-residents of Converse County $300.00 4. Perpetual Care $100.00 5. Recording of Deed As determined by the Converse County Clerk's 
Office 6. Memorial Marker Permit $25.00  
(Ord. 779 (part), 2006: Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
( Ord. No. 941, § 1, 10-28-2013 ; Ord. No. 975, § 1, 2-22-2016 ) 
12.24.070 - Perpetual care. 
    Perpetual care charges for cemetery spaces as set forth in Section 12.24.060(D) of this chapter shall be set aside in a special fund, invested in such lawful manner as deemed advisable, and the revenue from such fund shall be used only for the purpose of perpetuating the care, maintenance and upkeep of Douglas municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.080 - Burial charges. 
1. Open and close new grave: a. Infant burial $100.00 b. Cremations $100.00 c. All other burials $300.00 2. Disinterment, Cremains $150.00 plus cremation opening and closing fees 3. Disinterment, All Other $650.00 plus opening and closing fees 4. Reinterments $350.00 plus opening and closing fees 5. 6. In addition to the charges set forth in subsections 1 through 4, the following fees shall be assessed: a. Services occurring outside scheduled working hours or days. $250.00 b. Services occurring on designated city holidays. $500.00 7. No additional burial services shall be provided by the city unless the scope of services and charges for such services are expressly agreed upon in advance with the city administrator. 8. Disinterment or reinterment services that require the additional use of heavy equipment, as determined by the Parks and Recreation Director and/or the Cemetery Sexton, may incur additional costs for such equipment used. Opening and closing fees will also apply in addition to disinterment and re-interment fees. 9. The City of Douglas has no authority to determine what additional fees may be charged by any third party or vault company pertaining to any disinterment or reinterment into the Douglas Park Cemetery.  
(Ord. 779 (part), 2006: Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
( Ord. No. 975, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
12.24.090 - Burial permit required. 
    No burial will be permitted in any municipal cemetery until a burial permit has been issued showing that all purchase and burial fees have been paid. The burial permit shall also indicate the owner/purchaser, section, lot, block and space, date and time of funeral and any other information applicable for official records. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.110 - Disinterment and reinterment. 
    A permit for disinterment and reinterment shall be required prior to disinterment of a dead body or stillbirth, from one space to another space within the Douglas Park Cemetery, or to any location outside of the Douglas Park Cemetery, except as authorized by the State Department of Health regulations, a Court Order or otherwise provided by state law. The permit shall be issued by the local registrar or a licensed funeral director, embalmer, or other person acting as such, upon proper application. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
(Ord. No. 933, § 1, 3-14-2013) 
12.24.120 - Setting vaults. 
    Vaults are not required for burial in Douglas cemeteries. If vaults are desired, the setting of vaults shall be done under the guidelines as set forth in the rules and regulations governing the Douglas municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.130 - Installation of monuments. 
    No monuments, markers or structures used to mark or identify the location of an interment shall be placed within Douglas municipal cemeteries until a monument permit has been issued by the cemetery sexton and certification of ownership verified by the city administrator. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.140 - Decoration of graves. 
    Graves may be decorated and decorations removed under the guidelines as set forth in the rules and regulations governing the Douglas municipal cemeteries. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.150 - Resale of cemetery lots. 
    The resale of cemetery lots is prohibited, except back to the city. Such resale to the city shall be at the rate set by ordinance at the time of resale. A quit claim deed will be executed by the seller and recorded by the city. The cost of recording the deed will be borne by the seller. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
12.24.160 - Errors. 
    The city administrator shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made by him/her, or his/her designees, either in making interments, disinterments and removals or in the description, transfer and conveyance of any interment property. This may be done either by directing the canceling of such conveyance and substituting and conveying in lieu thereof other interment property of equal value or by refunding the amount of money paid on account of the purchase. In the event such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in such property, the city reserves the right to remove and transfer such remains so interred to such other property of equal value and similar locations as may be substituted in lieu thereof. The city, city administrator or other designees shall in no way be liable for any delay in the interment of a body where a protest to the interment has been made, or where there has been a failure to comply with the ordinance or rules and regulations. The city administrator shall be under no duty to recognize any protest of interment unless it is in writing and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. 590 (part), 1998) 
Chapter 12.28 - SPECIFIC RULES AND REGULATIONS 

12.28.010 - Authority to promulgate. 
    The use of streets, sidewalks and public places shall be subject to such specific rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the chief of police, fire chief, or city administrator; provided, that said rule or rules shall first be approved by the city council and that notice of such rule or rules is legibly posted at the location where said rule or regulation is to be enforced. Violation of such a posted rule or regulation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 500, 1991) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Division I. - Water System 
Chapter 13.04 - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION 

13.04.010 - Duties of governing body. 
    Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body shall fix all rates for water charges, tap fees and for services outside the corporate limits of the town and make regulations for the collection of the fees and charges. 
(Ord. 373 § 1-1, 1983) 
13.04.020 - Powers and duties of town administrator. 
A.  The town administrator, or his/her authorized representative, shall enforce all necessary rules, regulations and penalties to enforce the collection of fees or for the protection of the property and rights pertaining to the town's waterworks system. This authority shall include the power to make administrative rules or regulations as may be necessary to conserve the water supply and to prevent waste and unnecessary use of water including water restrictions. 
B.  The town administrator, or his/her designated representative, is authorized to issue a shutoff notice to any person who is two (2) months delinquent in payment of any water bill. Such person's water shall be shut off pursuant to Section 13.12.070 if the bill is not paid in full following shutoff notice. 
(Ord. 373 § 1-2, 1983) 
13.04.030 - Powers and duties of utility department director. 
    The utility department director shall be responsible for the distribution and treatment of the town's water system from the source of supply to service lines on the property side of the curb stop. 
(Ord. 373 § 1-3, 1983) 
13.04.040 - Interfering or tampering with waterworks-Polluting water supply. 
A.  No unauthorized person shall in any way interfere or tamper with any part of the town's water system, nor shall they do anything that will in any manner pollute or cause to pollute the water supply. Any person found guilty of polluting or tampering with the town's water supply shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
B.  No unauthorized person shall in any manner tamper with, deface or injure any fire hydrant nor shall the same be obstructed by any person in any manner so that free access to such hydrant cannot be readily had at all times for firefighting purposes. Any person found guilty of these acts shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 373 § 1-4, 1983) 
13.04.050 - Maintenance of service lines. 
A.  All property owners and consumers of water shall keep and maintain the service line beginning at the property side of the curb stop and shall keep the line in good repair and protect it from frost at their own expense. 
B.  The town shall not be responsible for payment of any claim resulting from the breakage of any pipe, meter or appurtenance attached thereto if the breakage occurs on the property side of the curb stop. 
(Ord. 373 § 1-5, 1983) 
13.04.060 - Water meters-Required. 
A.  All water delivered to any water users by means of the water system of the city shall be measured by meters. 
B.  Each single-family dwelling, multi-family building, business structure or mobile home park shall have a separate water meter. Condominiums, townhouses and/or duplex units shall be considered single-family units and shall have separate meters and shutoffs if each unit is individually owned. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 373 § 1-6, 1983) 
13.04.070 - Installation of meters-Generally. 
A.  As included in the fees set forth in Section 13.08.010, the city shall supply all meters installed in the city water system. All meters shall be installed with remote readout located on the outside of the structure or at the meter pit and accessible at all times to authorized personnel. 
B.  Meters shall be a minimum of three-fourths (3/4) inch inlet size. All meters installed prior to January 1, 2005 and located inside structures shall be installed and maintained in such a way that access is available at all reasonable hours. No pipes or other objects shall be installed in front of or adjacent to the meter. Sufficient room for removal of the meter must be available. Swivel connections shall be used and at least one (1) inch flexibility must be maintained in pipes to which meters are connected for proper removal for maintenance. Unless approved by utility department director, all water meters installed at structures constructed after January 1, 2005 shall be installed in meter pits as specified in the latest edition of the city amendments and supplements to the Wyoming Public Works Standard Specifications. Meters two (2) inches in diameter and larger shall be installed in reinforced concrete vaults; the design of the meter vaults shall be submitted to the city for approval prior to construction. 
C.  A gate valve must be installed in front of and behind the meter in order to allow isolation of the meter. 
D.  Any compound meter installed shall be installed horizontally to allow for proper repair and maintenance. 
E.  Each meter installed shall be protected by a city-approved seal. The seal shall not be broken without the utility department director's approval. Splices of any type will not be allowed in any readout cable and shall be considered as tampering with city property. No person shall tamper with readout cables or meter seals, install an illegal tap, bypass or in any way remove water from the city's system without going through the proper metered facility. Any person found guilty of a violation of this subsection shall be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 373 § 1-7, 1983) 
13.04.080 - Right of access to meters. 
    The utility department director, meter technician, or other authorized personnel of the city shall have free access at all reasonable hours to enter any premises where water is used, for the purpose of ascertaining any violation of any provisions of this chapter and to read, inspect, repair or remove for testing any water meter. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 1-8, 1983) 
13.04.090 - Ownership of meters-Maintenance. 
A.  All meters and remote readouts, including cable, are the property of the city. 
B.  The owner of the property upon which a meter is located shall assure that such meter is at all times in good working order, and shall contact the utility department director to cause the meter to be repaired or replaced. The property owner shall bear all cost of maintenance except for normal wear from operation. 
C.  City utility personnel shall remove and replace the meter if found defective and, unless damaged by the property owner or occupant, shall do so at no cost to the property owner. 
D.  If the property owner requests a test to verify meter accuracy, the meter shall be removed and tested by city personnel. All costs associated with testing shall be the responsibility of the property owner if no malfunction of the meter is found. If the meter is found to be faulty, the city shall pay all costs of meter testing. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 373 § 1-9, 1983) 
13.04.100 - Responsibility for taps or connections to water mains. 
A.  All taps or connections into any water main of the city shall be completed under the direction and supervision of an authorized employee of the city and subject to material and method approval by the city. No substitutions are allowed unless approval in writing is granted by the utility department director. 
B.  Any cost for taps including excavation, materials, tools, backfill, compaction and resurfacing of streets, and replacement of curb, gutter and sidewalks shall be done at the full expense of the property owner, developer or contractor. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 1-10, 1983) 
13.04.110 - Curb stops-Installation. 
A.  Curb stops shall be furnished and installed by a contractor licensed to work in the city for all structures to be served with water. 
B.  Single-family dwellings and businesses shall have curb stops installed within five (5) feet of the property line, at the back of the sidewalk if space allows; or within the sidewalk if the sidewalk abuts a building, set level with the sidewalk, and such curb stops shall be of a ferrous, metallic composition to allow for location by a magnetic or conductance locator. 
C.  Multiple-family dwellings shall have one (1) curb stop located within the public right-of-way as determined by the city, which shall provide shutoff service to the entire facility. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 1-11, 1983) 
13.04.130 - Bulk water. 
A.  No water shall be delivered in bulk to any user or customer for any reason for transportation within or outside the city unless such water shall be obtained from the city's fill station at the public works building. No bulk water shall be taken from any fire hydrant. For fees, refer to Section 13.12.060. 
B.  Utility department director may grant permission for temporary installation of any approved mobile fill station, provided a separate shutoff valve vacuum breaker and meter is provided by the user. Such permission shall be granted in writing. For fees, refer to Section 13.12.060. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 1-13, 1983) 
Chapter 13.06 - CROSS-CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW CONTROL 

13.06.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to comply with the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974, the Department of Environmental Quality Water Quality Rules and Regulations, the International Plumbing Code and to meet the following goals: 
A.  To protect the public potable water supply of the city from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating, within its customer's internal distribution system(s), such contaminants or pollutants which could backflow - to back siphon - into the public water system; 
B.  To promote the elimination or control of existing cross-connections, actual or potential, between the customer's in-plant potable water system(s) and non-potable system(s), plumbing fixtures, and industrial piping system(s); 
C.  To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-connection control, which will systematically prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to this chapter: 
A.  "Approved" means accepted by the utility department director as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this chapter or as suitable for the proposed use. 
B.  "Auxiliary water supply" means any water supply on or available to the water user's premises other than the city's approved public potable water supply. 
C.  "Backflow" means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances, under positive or reduced pressure into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply from any source other than its intended source. 
D.  "Backflow preventer" means an approved device or means designed to prevent backflow or back siphonage events from contaminating the potable water supply system. The most common devices are air gap, reduced pressure principal device, double check valve assembly, pressure vacuum breaker, atmospheric vacuum breaker, hose bibb vacuum breaker, residential dual check, double check with intermediate atmospheric vent, and barometric loop. 
E.  "Back pressure" means a condition in which the water user's system pressure is greater than the city's system pressure. 
F.  "Back siphonage" means the flow or water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply system through any source other than its intended source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. 
G.  "Certified backflow protection assembly tester" means a person who has passed an approved backflow protection assembly tester's certification examination. 
H.  "Check valve" means a self-closing assembly, which is designed to permit the flow of fluids in one direction. A single check valve is not an approved backflow prevention assembly. 
I.  "Containment" means the practice of installing approved backflow prevention devices at the water service connection of the water user in order to protect the public water supply from any backflow from the water user's system. 
J.  "Contamination" means an impairment of a public water supply by the introduction or admission of any foreign substance which degrades the quality of the potable water or creates a health hazard. 
K.  "Cross-connection" means any actual or potential connection between a potable water supply and any other source or system through which it is possible to introduce contamination into the system. 
L.  "Domestic services" means services using potable water for ordinary living processes not for commercial or industrial uses, fire protection systems with antifreeze or other chemicals, heating systems, etc. Examples may include residences, churches, office buildings, schools, etc. 
M.  "Dual check" means a device conforming to the American Society of Sanitary Engineering Standards No. 104, consisting of two (2) independently acting check valves. Dual check valves are allowed only for residential water service connections that have a low hazard potential with back pressure or back siphonage under continuous pressure. 
N.  "Fixture isolation" means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow preventer is located to correct a cross-connection at the fixture location rather than at a water service entrance. 
O.  "Hazard classification" means a determination by a hazard classification surveyor as to high hazard or low hazard and the potential cause of backflow as either back pressure or back siphonage. 
P.  "High hazard" means a situation created when any substance which is or may be introduced into a public water supply poses a threat to public health through poisoning, the spread of disease or pathogenic organisms, or any other public health concern. 
Q.  "Low hazard" means a situation created when any substance which is or may be introduced into a public water supply does not pose a threat to public health but which does adversely affect the aesthetic quality of the potable water. 
R.  "Water service connection" means any waterline or pipe connected to a distribution supply main or pipe for the purpose of conveying water to a water user's system. 
S.  "Water user" means any entity, whether public or private, with a water service connection to a public water supply. The water user is also identified as a customer of a public water supply. 
T.  "Water user system" means that portion of the user's water system between the water service connection and the point of use. This system includes all pipes, conduits, tanks, fixtures, and appurtenances used to convey, store or utilize water provided by the public water supply. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.030 - Responsibility. 
A.  The city has the responsibility of owning, operating and maintaining the public water system beginning at the source of supply and including adequate treatment facilities, the public water distribution system and service piping, ending at the point of delivery to the consumer's water system (service connection curb stop). 
B.  The city shall develop, adopt by resolution and implement a cross-connection control program in accordance with the minimum requirements set forth by the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality. The city shall exercise reasonable, informed judgment in assessing the degree of hazard posed to the public water system by all water users being served. 
C.  The city building official shall be responsible for reviewing building plans and inspection of plumbing as it is installed, so as to prevent cross-connections from being designed and built into structures within the city's jurisdiction. The building official's inspection responsibility begins at the curb stop connection or water meter pit and continues throughout the entire extent of the customer's potable water system. Approved backflow prevention devices shall be indicated on the construction plans as determined by the degree of hazard that the inspector reasonably determines will be present, and such devices shall be properly installed. 
D.  The water user has the primary responsibility for preventing pollutants and contaminants from entering his/her potable water system or the public water system. The water user's responsibility starts at the point of delivery (service connection curb stop) and includes all of his/her internal water system. The water user, at his/her own expense, shall install, operate, test and maintain approved backflow prevention devices as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.040 - Degree of hazard. 
    The city recognizes the threat to the public water system arising from cross-connections. All threats will be classified based upon the degree of hazard of the cross-connection and the cause of the potential backflow. Hazards shall be classified as high hazard or low hazard. The potential cause of the backflow shall be identified as being back siphonage or back pressure. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.050 - Residential water service connections. 
    Residential water service connections shall be considered to be low hazard, back siphonage connections, unless determined otherwise by a hazard classification. Residential dual check devices for structures existing at the time of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be replaced under a program as referenced in Section 13.06.030(B) of this chapter and funded through the water department capital replacement fund. Installation of residential dual check devices shall be installed as water meters are replaced throughout the community with the goal of installing all such systems within sixty (60) months from passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.060 - New residential water users. 
    All new residential developments will be required to install a residential dual check device at the water user's expense downstream of the water meter before any certificate of occupancy will be issued for the structure. 
    The water user shall be notified that installation of a backflow prevention assembly device results in a potential closed plumbing system within his/her residence. As such, provisions may have to be made by the water user to provide for thermal expansion within his/her closed loop system. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.070 - Commercial, industrial or other high hazard water users. 
A.  Commercial or industrial water users shall, at their own expense, install, maintain, and test, or have tested, any and all backflow preventers beyond the water service connection, pursuant to Section 13.06.090. 
B.  Commercial or industrial water service connections shall be considered to be high hazard back pressure connections, unless determined otherwise by the hazard classification. For premises existing prior to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter, the city will perform evaluation and inspections of plans and/or premises under its cross-connection program. 
1.  If such water users are determined to be low hazard, the water user shall be required to install appropriate cross-connection device within sixty (60) months of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
2.  If such water users are determined to be high hazard, the city shall notify such water user by letter of the need to install a suitable cross-connection device or to correct any existing faulty cross-connection device installation, the method of achieving the correction, and the time allowed for the installation or correction to be made. In no case shall a high hazard water service connection be allowed to delay installation or corrective action for more than ninety (90) days from date of inspection. This time period may be shortened depending upon the degree of hazard involved. 
C.  Failure to comply with the designated deadline shall subject the water user to a termination of water services within a period not to exceed five (5) days for failure to comply with the requirements of this section. In the event the water user informs the city of extenuating circumstances as to why the correction has not been made, a time extension may be granted by the department but in no case will it exceed one thirty (30) day extension. 
D.  If the city determines at any time that a serious threat to the public health exists, the water service may be terminated immediately and without prior notification. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.080 - Standards for installation of backflow prevention assemblies. 
A.  Before any backflow prevention assembly is installed for the prevention of backflow, the city shall first approve such assembly. Assembly shall be installed and tested for conformity with recognized standards acceptable to the city, which are consistent with the International Plumbing Code, city utility construction specifications and Department of Environmental Quality regulations. 
B.  Existing backflow prevention assembly installations that are not approved shall be replaced with an approved assembly within ninety (90) days written notice from city. 
C.  Approved assemblies shall not be modified in any way after the assembly leaves the manufacturer's factory. If installation is not completed by a plumber licensed with the city, completed installation shall be inspected by a plumber licensed with the city. Upon completion of installation or inspection, the licensed plumber shall notify the city of the installation. 
D.  Installation requirements complying with the International Plumbing Code shall be followed in access and clearance for the required testing, maintenance and repair of all assemblies. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.090 - Testing and maintenance. 
A.  It is the duty of the water user of any premises protected with a testable backflow prevention assembly to have such assembly tested annually or as directed by the city, at the water user's expense. 
B.  Any assembly that leaks, malfunctions or fails a test shall be repaired or replaced and retested upon notification of such failure by the tester and/or written notice from the city of the failure within five (5) working days of receipt of such notice. High hazard situations will not be allowed to continue unprotected if the backflow preventer fails the test and cannot be repaired immediately. 
C.  The city reserves the right to spot check and test any containment assembly at any time to verify the proper operation and test results of the assembly. 
D.  The water user shall be responsible for the payment of all fees for permits, device testing, retesting in the case that the device fails to operate correctly, and second reinspections for non-compliance with city requirements. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.100 - Right of entry. 
    The city utility department director or his/her designee shall, during normal business hours and upon display of proper credentials, have the right to enter all buildings being served from the public water system for the purpose of inspection of cross-connections and existing or potential hazards. The right of entry shall be a condition of continuing water service in order to provide assurance that the health, safety and welfare are maintained for the community within the water distribution system of the city. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
13.06.120 - Violations. 
    Failure of the water user to cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing or inspection of backflow prevention assemblies required by the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be grounds for the termination of water service to the premises. 
    Water service may be terminated by the city if unprotected cross-connections exist on the premises. When any defect is found in an installed backflow prevention assembly, or if the backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed, water service may be terminated. Service shall not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. 
    Termination of service may be summary, immediate and without written notice whenever, in the judgment of the city, such action is necessary to protect the purity of the public potable water system supply or the safety of the water system. 
(Ord. 728 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.08 - PLANT INVESTMENT FEES 

13.08.010 - Determination of amount-Responsibility. 
A.  All charges for connection to the city's water system made pursuant hereto shall be paid by the owner of the property, developer or contractor and shall be paid to the city upon issuance of the tap permit. A right-of-way permit will be required for excavation onto city right-of-way or other public land. 
B.  The plant investment fee for connections to the city water system shall be determined by the following schedule. For metered connections larger than four (4) inches in diameter, the plant investment fee shall be negotiated by the city administrator based upon projected water usage at the facility versus the maximum flow rate through a one (1) inch diameter meter.

1.  The base plant investment fee is assessed to new development to cover the development's share of the system capacity, including water sources, treatment, transmission, pumping and storage, and is intended to cover the proposed customer's pro-rata share of these capital facilities. 
2.  Included in the total plant investment fees above is the cost and installation of the meter and the remote readout and meter activation charges. The plant investment fee does not include the cost for tapping the water main and the installation of the service line, corporation stop, curb stop, meter pit and all associated excavation and surface restoration. The property owner, developer or contractor will be responsible for the costs of installing the service line to the property and the service connection pursuant to Section 13.04.100(B) of this chapter. 
3.  Any property served by the city outside the corporate limits shall be charged one and one-half (1.5) times the total plant investment fees indicated in this section. The connection fee for a separate fire-fighting line connection shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), provided this line is not used to provide the everyday water supply to the structure. 
4.  The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
(Ord. 836 (part), 2008; Ord. 828 (part), 2008; Ord. 611 (part), 2000; Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 395, 1984: Ord. 373 § 21, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 904, § 2, 7-25-2011) 
13.08.020 - Right-of-way permits required. 
A.  For excavation in city right-of-way or other public land, a right-of-way permit shall be obtained from the community development department. The permit shall cover such items as: excavation, materials, backfill, compaction, replacement of asphalt or concrete paving, replacement of curb, gutter, and sidewalks and any other materials required for complete restoration of the trenched area. 
B.  All excavated areas shall be compacted to city specifications and, prior to replacing any surfacing, contractor shall contact the community development department for soils testing and approval of compaction. 
C.  In the case of failure of the excavation or surfacing, even with testing, the party causing the excavation shall be fully responsible for replacing the same for a period of one (1) year after completion of the work. In the event the contractor refuses to repair such failure, the town may, at its discretion, order the work to be done by another party and bill such cost back to the original permittee. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 373 § 2-2, 1983) 
Chapter 13.10 - USE OF PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM REQUIRED 

13.10.010 - Connection to city water system required. 
A.  The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public water distribution line of the city, is required at the owner's expense to install suitable potable water facilities for each individual residence and/or commercial business and each separate property owner therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public water line in accordance with the provisions of this division and adopted public works standards within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so. Failure to separate services within the allotted time may result in a fine up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). The public works director or designee may extend the ninety (90) day deadline to separate services at his or her discretion. 
B.  The city requires that any property or area to be served by the water system of the city be annexed into the city prior to the provision or installation of water services. 
(Ord. 566 (part), 1997) 
( Ord. No. 949, § 2, 5-27-2014 ; Ord. No. 994 , § 1, 2-12-2018) 
13.10.020 - On-site water system prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful to construct or maintain any private well within the city limits intended to be used as potable water. 
B.  Individual property owners may, at their own expense and upon approval from the State Engineer and other licensing authority, install private wells for irrigation purposes only. 
C.  Before commencement of construction of a private well for irrigation purposes, the owner shall first obtain written permission from the governing body. The request for such shall include any plans, specifications, and other information as is deemed necessary by the governing body. 
(Ord. 573 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 13.12 - USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

13.12.010 - Generation of revenue. 
    The user charge system shall generate adequate annual revenues to pay costs of annual operation and maintenance including replacement and other related water system costs which the city may determine by ordinance to be paid by the user charge system. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 3-1, 1983) 
13.12.020 - Billing status. 
    It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the city of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing requirements. The application for service or for change of name or billing shall be made upon the appropriate forms available at the City Hall. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 3-2, 1983) 
13.12.030 - Improper water use. 
    Any person who shall knowingly take water from the city's supply without first having established an account shall pay the city for the estimated water used, plus pay the penalty of a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such unlawful taking of water. Water shall be shut off from such premises until such charges and/or penalties are paid. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 3-3, 1983) 
13.12.040 - Rates and charges. 
A.  All metered structures shall be assessed a monthly water rate consisting of a customer service charge, a demand charge and a commodity charge. 
B.  The customer service charge shall be assessed to recover costs that apply equally to each user of the system regardless of demand or quantity used. It shall be billed on a customer account basis. 
C.  The demand charge shall be assessed to recover costs of debt service and replacement fund for water facilities. It shall be based on the size of the customer's meter or service as follows:

The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year.
