The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
(Ord. 836 (part), 2008; Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 787, 2007; Ord. 776 (part), 2006; Ord. 707 (part), 2003; Ord. 691 (part), 2003; Ord. 631 (part), 2001; Ord. 611 (part), 2000; Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 529 (part), 1994; Ord. 514 (part), 1992; Ord. 390 (part), 1984; Ord. 373 § 3-4, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 873, 2-22-2010; Res. No. 1706, § 1, 6-13-2011; Ord. No. 904, § 3, 7-25-2011; Res. No. 1871, § 2, 6-22-2015 ; Res. No. 1908, § 2, 6-27-2016 ; Res. No. 1939 , § 2, 6-26-2017) 
13.12.050 - Vacant units. 
A.  Vacant units will not be charged for water service if the service is discontinued by the city and the city has been properly informed in writing that a unit is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days. After notification of discontinuance, the water at that residence shall be turned off at the curb. The owner shall be assessed a fee as indicated in Section 13.12.040(E). If the property owner requests that the meter be pulled from a unit, property owner shall be assessed a fee as indicated in Section 13.12.040(E). Reconnect fees shall be as indicated in Section 13.12.040(E). 
(Ord. 691 (part), 2003; Ord. 529 (part), 1994: Ord. 373 § 3-5, 1983) 
13.12.060 - Bulk water sales. 
A.  Treated water delivered through the city's fill station shall be sold at a rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per thousand (1,000) gallons, with the exception of any user who is under an agreement with the city pursuant to Wyoming Statute Section 41-3-110, as amended, and purchases treated water delivered through the city's fill station, which shall be sold at a rate of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per thousand (1,000) gallons. Untreated or raw water pumped from the river at the city's point of diversion shall be charged at a rate negotiated by the city administrator. Raw water shall be sold for irrigation or construction purposes only. 
B.  The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution. 
(Ord. 799, 2007: Ord. 373 § 3-6, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 878, 3-8-2010; Ord. No. 903, §§ 1, 2, 7-25-2011; Res. No. 1742, 7-9-2012) 
13.12.070 - Monthly billing dates and delinquent accounts. 
A.  Property owner shall be responsible for payment of all utility bills unless property owner assigns tenant responsibility for payment of such bills. Such assignment shall be in writing. All utility bills shall be sent to the property owner or tenant on a monthly basis. All monthly charges for water shall be due and payable on the twentieth of each month. If payment is not made by the twentieth of the month, the account shall be deemed delinquent and account shall be subject to a five dollar ($5.00) rebilling charge. If payment is not received within thirty (30) days after initial billing, a letter shall be sent to the owner and tenant at the mailing address(es) on file. The letter shall state: 
1.  That the account is delinquent; 
2.  That if the account is not paid in full on or before sixty (60) days after the initial billing (giving the date of the sixtieth day), the account shall be deemed in default and services discontinued; and 
3.  That the bill may be contested or challenged by contacting the city finance office (giving address and telephone number) prior to the fiftieth day after initial billing (giving the date of the fiftieth day). If payment of the account in full is not received or if the account is not settled within sixty (60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in default and services discontinued. 
B.  Any residential, or commercial, property owner or tenant who has had the water shutoff for nonpayment of utility charges shall pay the bill in its entirety for all utility charges including water, sewer, garbage, landfill, pest control, etc., and shall deposit with the city a sum equivalent to two (2) times the average monthly bill for all municipal utility services for that property prior to service being restored. 
C.  For provisions concerning turn-on/turn-off fees, see Section 13.12.040. 
D.  All deposits shall be held for a period of one (1) year. If the property owner or tenant demonstrates good faith in payment of bills in a timely fashion, the deposit shall be returned. 
E.  If the property owner or tenant cannot demonstrate good faith in payment of the bill, the deposit shall be held by the city until such time of final billing. Final billing shall be made and deducted from moneys on deposit and any balance returned to the property owner or tenant. The property owner or tenant shall be responsible for payment of the final bill in total if the deposit does not fully satisfy the debt to the city. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 691 (part), 2003; Ord. 529 (part), 1994: Ord. 422, 1984: Ord. 373 § 3-7, 1983) 
Chapter 13.16 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

13.16.010 - Replacement account. 
    The city will establish and maintain a funded replacement reserve account throughout the useful life of the water supply and treatment works. One hundred percent (100%) of the estimated annual depreciation expense per year shall be credited to this reserve until a total of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) is accumulated. This account may be used for replacement or repairs necessary to assure the supply, treatment and distribution works reaching their useful life. In the event any portion of the fund is used, deposits shall be resumed to maintain the balance of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00). 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 529 (part), 1994: Ord. 448, 1986: Ord. 390 (part), 1984: Ord. 373 § 4-1, 1983) 
13.16.030 - Regulations promulgated by the governing body. 
    The governing body, at its discretion, may establish rules and regulations for watering, distribution and operation of the water system as deemed fit and necessary. This article, when implemented by the governing body, shall be enforced by the Douglas police department. 
(Ord. 373 § 4-3, 1983) 
13.16.040 - Access to meters and read-out. 
    If a meter or remote read-out cannot be read because of locked gates, the presence of a dog or any other obstacle preventing the meter reader or any other agent of the city from obtaining a reading, a written notice will be given to the owner to remove such obstacle and make the meter or read-out accessible. 
(Ord. 373 § 4-4, 1983) 
13.16.060 - Liability for negligence. 
    If any person, other than authorized city personnel, working on the city's water distribution system in any manner damages, destroys or causes the city system to be drained of water, that party shall be responsible and liable for the loss of any water and such additional fee or costs as determined by the city shall be assessed accordingly. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 4-6, 1983) 
13.16.070 - Restriction on watering. 
A.  If in the opinion of the governing body, city administrator, or the utility department director, watering restrictions are deemed necessary, such hours of restricted use shall be determined by the seriousness of the water shortage. Public notice shall be given utilizing all reasonable media. 
B.  Any violation of the hours for watering is declared to be unlawful and such violation of any regulation shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 373 § 4-7, 1983) 
Division II. - Sewer System 
Chapter 13.20 - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION 

13.20.010 - Duties of governing body. 
    Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body shall fix all rates for sewer charges, septic waste disposal facility charges, connection fees and for services to users within the service area of the city and make regulations for the collection of the fees and charges. 
(Ord. 518 § 1, 1993: Ord. 375 § 1-1, 1983) 
13.20.020 - Powers and duties of town administrator. 
    The town administrator, or his authorized representative, shall enforce all necessary rules, regulations and penalties to enforce the collection of fees or for the protection of the property and rights pertaining to the town's wastewater system. This authority shall include the power to make any administrative rules or regulations as may be necessary to remain in compliance with EPA guidelines. 
(Ord. 375 § 1-2, 1983) 
13.20.030 - Powers and authority of utility department director. 
A.  The utility department director and other duly authorized employees of the town bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and Chapters 13.24 through 13.48 of this title. 
B.  The utility department director or other duly authorized employees are authorized to obtain information concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the wastewater collection system. The industry may withhold information considered confidential. The industry must establish that the revelation to the public of the information in question might result in an advantage to a competitor. 
C.  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection A of this section, the utility department director or duly authorized employees of the town shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless of injury or death to the town employees and the town shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by town employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury for property damage asserted against the company growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required. 
D.  The utility department director and other duly authorized employees bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the town holds a duly executed easement for the purposes of, but not limited to inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly executed easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. 375 § 1-3, 1983) 
13.20.040 - Interfering or tampering with wastewater treatment facilities. 
    No person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the wastewater facility. Any person found guilty of violating this provision shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), not including any civil liability which may be determined for such damage. 
(Ord. 375 § 1-4, 1983) 
13.20.050 - Falsifying information. 
    Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certification in any application, record, report, plan, or other document filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this division, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this division, shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties as provided in Section 1.12.010 of the Douglas Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 518 § 2, 1993) 
Chapter 13.24 - DEFINITIONS 

13.24.010 - Generally. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this division of this title shall be as set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. 375 Ch.2 (part), 1983) 
13.24.015 - Act or the Act. 
    "Act" or "the Act" means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251, et seq. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.020 - Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD). 
    "Biochemical oxygen demand" or "BOD" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20ï¿1/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/2C), expressed in milligrams per liter. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-1, 1983) 
13.24.030 - Building drain. 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-2, 1983) 
13.24.040 - Building sewer. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called "house connection," "lateral," or "service line." 
(Ord. 375 § 2-3, 1983) 
13.24.050 - Combined sewer. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer intended to receive both wastewater and storm or surface water (not allowed in the town). 
(Ord. 375 § 2-4, 1983) 
13.24.060 - Easement. 
    "Easement" means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-5, 1983) 
13.24.070 - Floatable oil. 
    "Floatable oil" means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-6, 1983) 
13.24.080 - Garbage. 
    "Garbage" means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-7, 1983) 
13.24.082 - Hazardous waste. 
    "Hazardous waste" is any waste listed as a hazardous waste in Subpart D, Section 261.30 of the Code of Federal Regulations. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.084 - Holding tank waste. 
    "Holding tank waste" means any domestic sanitary waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.090 - Industrial wastes. 
    "Industrial wastes" means the wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-8, 1983) 
13.24.095 - Interference. 
    "Interference" means the inhibition or disruption of the wastewater treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.100 - Natural outlet. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, point, ditch, lake or other body of surface or ground water. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-9, 1983) 
13.24.110 - Normal domestic wastewater. 
    "Normal domestic wastewater" means wastewater that has a BOD concentration of not more than three hundred (300) milligrams per liter and a suspended solids concentration of not more than three hundred (300) milligrams per liter. Normal domestic wastewater is considered to have a concentration which will generally range from approximately one hundred twenty-five (125) to three hundred (300) milligrams per liter of both BOD and suspended solids. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-10, 1983) 
13.24.120 - Operation and maintenance. 
    "Operation and maintenance" means expenditures during the useful life of the treatment works for materials, labor, utilities and other items which are necessary for managing and maintaining the sewage works to achieve the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-11, 1983) 
13.24.130 - Person. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-12, 1983) 
13.24.140 - pH. 
    "pH" means the reciprocal of the logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven (7) and a hydrogen ion concentration of 10 -7 . 
(Ord. 375 § 2-13, 1983) 
13.24.145 - Pollutant. 
    "Pollutant" means any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into water. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.146 - Pollution. 
    "Pollution" means the man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.150 - Properly shredded garbage. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-14, 1983) 
13.24.160 - Public sewer. 
    "Public sewer" means a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility; a sewer main. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-15, 1983) 
13.24.170 - Replacement. 
    "Replacement" means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary in the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-16, 1983) 
13.24.180 - Residential contributor. 
    "Residential contributor" means any contributor to the town treatment works whose lot, parcel of real estate or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes only. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-17, 1983) 
13.24.190 - Sanitary sewer. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface water that are not admitted intentionally. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-18, 1983) 
13.24.194 - Septic waste. 
    "Septic waste" refers to trucked or hauled nonhazardous sanitary domestic waste, as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.195 - Septic waste disposal facility. 
    "Septic waste disposal facility" means that facility designated for the discharge of domestic sanitary wastes into the city's wastewater treatment facility. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.200 - Sewage. 
    "Sewage" means that spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater," as defined in Section 13.24.300. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-19, 1983) 
13.24.210 - Sewer. 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-20, 1983) 
13.24.220 - Shall-May. 
    "Shall" is mandatory. "May" is permissive. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-21, 1983) 
13.24.225 - Sludge. 
    "Sludge" means any solid, semi-solid or liquid waste generated from a municipal, commercial or industrial wastewater treatment plant, water treatment plant, or air pollution control facility exclusive of the treated effluent from a wastewater treatment plant. 
(Ord. 518 § 3 (part), 1993) 
13.24.230 - Slug. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-22, 1983) 
13.24.240 - Storm drain-Storm sewer. 
    "Storm drain" (sometimes termed "storm sewer") means a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted water from any source. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-23, 1983) 
13.24.250 - Suspended solids (SS). 
    "Suspended solids" or "SS" means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-24, 1983) 
13.24.260 - Treatment works. 
    "Treatment works" means any devices and systems for the storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage, domestic sewage or liquid industrial waste. These include items, individual systems, pumping, power and other equipment appurtenances; extensions, improvement, remodeling, additions and alterations thereof; elements essential to provide a reliable recycling supply such as standby treatment units and clear-well facilities; and any works including site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment process or is used for ultimate disposal of residue resulting from such treatment; or any other method or system of preventing, abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal waste or industrial waste, including waste and combined stormwater and sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-25, 1983) 
13.24.270 - Unpolluted water. 
    "Unpolluted water" means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-26, 1983) 
13.24.280 - Useful life. 
    "Useful life" means the estimated period during which a treatment works will be operating. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-27, 1983) 
13.24.290 - User charge. 
    "User charge" means that portion of the total wastewater service charge which is levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement of the wastewater treatment works. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-28, 1983) 
13.24.300 - Wastewater. 
    "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-29, 1983) 
13.24.310 - Wastewater facilities. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the public structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-30, 1983) 
13.24.320 - Wastewater treatment works. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. The term is sometimes used as synonymous with "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control plant." 
(Ord. 375 § 2-31, 1983) 
13.24.330 - Watercourse. 
    "Watercourse" means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-33, 1983) 
13.24.340 - Water meter. 
    "Water meter" means a water volume measuring and recording device furnished and/or installed by the town. 
(Ord. 375 § 2-34, 1983) 
Chapter 13.28 - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED 

13.28.010 - Deposit of garbage in unsanitary manner prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable waste. 
(Ord. 375 § 3-1, 1983) 
13.28.020 - Discharge of untreated wastewater prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(Ord. 375 § 3-2, 1983) 
13.28.030 - On-site disposal system prohibited. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. 375 § 3-3, 1983) 
13.28.035 - Trucked or hauled sanitary domestic septage-Septic waste disposal facility. 
A.  The discharge of trucked and hauled sanitary domestic septage, except as provided in subsection D below, by any individual, firm or corporation is prohibited at any location except at the city septic waste disposal facility located at the city wastewater treatment plant. 
B.  The septic waste disposal facility will accept only sanitary domestic waste from sanitary septic sources from the following sources: 
1.  Residential homes; 
2.  Domestic wastes from sanitary septic sources within a business; 
3.  Greases and oils from approved restaurants/hotels with domestic sanitary wastes only. 
C.  No oil field wastes, produced waters, or other chemically based waters used or found in the oil, mining or other production process will be accepted. 
D.  Recreational vehicles and camper trailers may utilize designated septic waste dumping stations within the city limits to discharge sanitary waste holding tank contents not exceeding one hundred (100) gallons. 
(Ord. 518 § 4 (part), 1993) 
13.28.037 - Regulation-Septic waste disposal facility. 
    The city council shall from time to time and by resolution, adopt, amend and update regulations and guidelines governing the use of the septic waste disposal facility. The city council shall annually review the user charge system and revise the system as necessary to assure equity of the system and to assure that sufficient funds will be collected from the system to adequately operate and maintain the septic waste disposal facility. Failure to conduct the annual review shall be grounds for the initiation of a current review process only and shall not invalidate existing fee schedules which shall remain in effect until modified by affirmative council action. 
(Ord. 518 § 4 (part), 1993) 
13.28.040 - Connection to town wastewater system required-Annexation. 
A.  The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the town and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the town, is required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within two hundred (200) feet of the property line. 
B.  The town requires that at the direction of the governing body, any area served by the wastewater system of the town be annexed to the town or commit to annexation within one (1) year. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 375 § 3-4, 1983) 
Chapter 13.32 - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 

13.32.010 - When allowed. 
    Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of Section 13.28.040, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of Chapters 13.20 through 13.48 of this title. 
(Ord. 375 § 4-1, 1983) 
13.32.020 - Permission required-Procedure. 
A.  Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system, the owner(s) shall first obtain written permission from the governing body. The request for such shall include any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the governing body. The approval of the county sanitarian is also required. Permits for on-site wastewater disposal shall be issued by sanitarian's office. 
B.  A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the county sanitarian. The sanitarian shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the sanitarian when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. 
(Ord. 375 § 4-2, 1983) 
13.32.030 - Connection to public sewer required when available. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, as defined in Chapter 13.20, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within ninety (90) days in compliance with Division II of this title, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with sand. 
(Ord. 375 § 4-3, 1983) 
13.32.040 - Responsibility for maintenance of private system. 
    The owner(s) shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the town. 
(Ord. 375 § 4-5, 1983) 
13.32.050 - Additional requirements of sanitarian. 
    No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county sanitarian or the county board of health. 
(Ord. 375 § 4-6, 1983) 
Chapter 13.36 - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

13.36.010 - Permit required for work on sewer system. 
    No unauthorized person(s) shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the community development department. For excavation in a city right-of-way or other public land, a right-of-way permit shall be obtained from the community development department. The permit shall cover such items as: excavation, materials, backfill, compaction, replacement of asphalt or concrete paving, replacement of curb, gutter and sidewalks and any other materials required for complete restoration of the trenched area. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 375 § 5-1, 1983) 
13.36.020 - Plant investment fee required. 
A.  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 
Class A For residential and commercial service; 
Class B For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
B.  In either case, the owner(s) or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the community development and public works departments. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 375 § 5-2, 1983) 
13.36.030 - Responsibility for costs of installation. 
    All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the property owner, developer or contractor. Plant investment fee shall be paid to the city at the time of the issuance of the tap permit. The owner(s) shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. Fees shall be as indicated in Section 13.44.040. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 375 § 5-3, 1983) 
13.36.040 - Separate sewer service line required for each structure or dwelling unit. 
    A separate and independent sewer service line shall be provided for every building, single family dwelling, multi-family dwelling, business structure or mobile home park. Condominiums, townhouses and/or duplex units shall be considered single-family units and shall have separate sewer service lines if each unit is individually owned, or is capable of individual ownership. 
(Ord. 669, 2003: Ord. 375 § 5-4, 1983) 
13.36.050 - Old building sewers in new buildings. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination of the community development department, to meet all requirements of this chapter and no new tap is made to a city main. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 375 § 5-5, 1983) 
13.36.060 - Proper design and construction of new sewer and connections. 
A.  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of all sanitary sewers and sewer connections, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code and other applicable rules and regulations of the city and the state. 
B.  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
C.  The connections of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the community development department before installation. 
D.  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the public works department when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the public works department. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 375 § 5-6, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 987 , § 1, 2-13-2017) 
13.36.070 - Surface and groundwater drainage connection prohibited-Exception. 
    No person(s) shall make connections of roof downspouts, foundations drains, areaways drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the public works department with concurrence from the city administrator. Approval may be subject to conditions or restrictions as determined by public works. 
(Ord. No. 987 , § 2, 2-13-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 987 , § 2, adopted Feb. 13, 2017, repealed § 13.36.070 and enacted a new § 13.36.070 as set out herein. The former § 13.36.070 pertained to surface drainage connection prohibited-exceptions and derived from Ord. 576 (part), adopted 1997; and Ord. 375 § 5-7, adopted 1983. 
13.36.080 - Safety precautions during excavation-Restoration of premises. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the town. 
(Ord. 375 § 5-8, 1983) 
13.36.090 - Responsibility for maintenance. 
    All property owners connected to the town's wastewater treatment facility shall keep and maintain the lateral line from the building connection to the public sewer main, and shall keep the line in good repair at their own expense. The town shall not be responsible for payment of any claim resulting from the breakage of any line or for damage resulting from backup of sewer if the breakage or backup occurs in the lateral line. 
(Ord. 375 § 5-9, 1983) 
Chapter 13.40 - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 

13.40.010 - Discharge of unpolluted waters prohibited-Exception. 
A.  No persons shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sewer, except stormwater runoff from limited areas, unless such connection is approved by the public works department with concurrence from the city administrator. Approval may be subject to conditions or restrictions as determined by public works. 
B.  Stormwater, other than that exempted under subsection A of this section, and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the public works director and other regulatory agencies, or to a sanitary sewer with the approval of public works and concurrence of the city administrator as provided for in Section 13.36.070. Unpolluted industrial cooling water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the public works director, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. 518 § 5, 1993: Ord. 375 § 6-1, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 987 , § 3, 2-13-2017) 
13.40.015 - Specific pollutant limitations designated. 
    No person shall discharge any wastewater or other substance into the wastewater treatment plant containing the following substances in excess of the listed total concentration limitations:
