    Any other specific pollutants identified by the city may also have specific effluent permit limitations set by the city to restrict their discharge into the system. 
(Ord. 518 § 6, 1993) 
13.40.020 - Prohibited materials designated. 
    No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operations or performance of the wastewater treatment plant or septic waste disposal facility. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of the wastewater treatment facility whether or not the user is subject to National Categorical Pretreatment Standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. A user may not contribute the following substances to the wastewater treatment plant or septic waste disposal facility: 
A.  Any liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the wastewater treatment facility or to the operation of the wastewater treatment facility, including, but not limited to, wastestreams with a closed cup flash-point of less than one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit (140°F.) or sixty degrees Celsius (60°C.) using test methods in 40 CFR 261.21, as enacted or hereafter amended. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system) be more than five percent (5%), nor any single reading over ten percent (10%) of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides, and any other substances which the city, the state, or EPA has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the system; 
B.  Solid or viscous substances which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to: grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone, or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastics, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining, or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes; 
C.  Petroleum-based oil in sufficient enough amounts that cause pass-through or interference to the system, and in no cases exceeding one hundred (100) mg/l; 
D.  Any wastewater having a pH less than five (5.0) or greater than twelve (12.0), or wastewater having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and/or personnel of the wastewater treatment facility; 
E.  Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, result in toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the wastewater treatment facility in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems, create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment facility, or to exceed the limitation set forth in a categorical standard. A toxic pollutant shall include but not be limited to any pollutant identified pursuant to Section 307(a) of the Act; 
F.  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, or solids which either singly or by interaction with other wastes are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the public sewers for maintenance and repair; 
G.  Any substance which may cause the wastewater treatment facility's effluent or any other product of the wastewater treatment facility such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. In no case shall a substance discharged to the wastewater treatment facility cause the wastewater treatment facility to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under Section 405 of the Act; any criteria, guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used; 
H.  Any substance which will cause the wastewater treatment facility to violate its NPDES and/or State Disposal System Permit or the receiving water quality standards; 
I.  Any wastewater with objectionable color which cannot be removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions; 
J.  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the wastewater treatment facility resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater with a temperature above sixty-five degrees Celsius (65ï¿1/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/2C.) (one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150ï¿1/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/2F.) or a temperature that causes the wastewater treatment facility influent to exceed forty degrees Celsius (40ï¿1/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/2C.) (one hundred four degrees Fahrenheit (104ï¿1/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/21/2F.); 
K.  Any pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which a user knows or has reason to know will cause interference to the wastewater treatment facility. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain concentration or quantities of pollutants that exceed limits set by the utility department director; 
L.  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
M.  Any wastewater which causes a hazard to human life or creates a public nuisance. 
(Ord. 518 § 7, 1993: Ord. 375 § 6-2, 1983) 
13.40.040 - Powers of utility department director concerning abuse. 
A.  If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, any of the substances listed in subsections (A) through (M) of Section 13.40.030 in such amounts as to have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the utility department director may: 
1.  Reject the wastes; or 
2.  Advise the user of the impact of the contribution to the wastewater treatment facility; and, 
3.  Develop effluent limitations for such user to correct the interference with the wastewater treatment facility; 
4.  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; and/or 
5.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
6.  Require payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
B.  If the utility department director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the community development department. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 518 § 9, 1993: Ord. 375 § 6-4, 1983) 
13.40.041 - Federal categorical pretreatment standards. 
    Upon the promulgation of the categorical standard for a particular industrial subcategory, the standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed under this division for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this division. The utility department director shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting requirements under 40 CFR 403.12, as enacted or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. 518 § 10 (part), 1993) 
13.40.042 - State requirements to apply when. 
    State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this division. 
(Ord. 518 § 10 (part), 1993) 
13.40.045 - Increasing or diluting discharge to avoid proper treatment prohibited. 
    No user shall increase the use of process water or, in any way, attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in the categorical standard, or in any other pollutant-specific limitation developed by the city or state. 
(Ord. 518 § 10 (part), 1993) 
13.40.050 - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil, catchbasins and sand interceptors shall be provided or modified when, in the opinion of the utility department director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts, as specified in Section 13.40.020(B), or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. Modifications to existing interceptors may be required when violations of this division exist. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the utility department director and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal, which are subject to review by the utility department director. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the owner's personnel must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal firms. 
(Ord. 518 § 11, 1993: Ord. 375 § 6-5, 1983) 
13.40.060 - Pretreatment or flow equalizing facilities-Owner responsibility. 
    Where pretreatment of flow equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner(s) at his expense. 
(Ord. 375 § 6-6, 1983) 
13.40.070 - Industrial waste monitoring device. 
    When required by the city, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such structure, when required, shall be accessible to city personnel and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the community development department. The structure shall be installed by the owner at his/her expense and shall be maintained by him/her so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 375 § 6-7, 1983) 
13.40.080 - Tests and sampling standards. 
    All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling methods, location, times, duration and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the utility department director. 
(Ord. 375 § 6-8, 1983) 
13.40.090 - Special arrangements for industrial users. 
    No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. 
(Ord. 375 § 6-9, 1983) 
Chapter 13.44 - USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

13.44.010 - Purpose. 
    It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to the protection of the public health, safety and welfare to collect charges from all users who contribute wastewater to the city's treatment works. The proceeds of such charges so derived will be used for the purpose of operation and maintenance and other related costs as determined by the city council for such public wastewater treatment works. 
(Ord. 375 § 7-1, 1983) 
13.44.020 - Generation of revenue. 
    The user charge system shall generate adequate annual revenues to pay costs of annual operation and maintenance including replacement and other related sewer system costs which the city may determine by ordinance to be paid by the user charge system. That portion of the total user charge which is designated for operation and maintenance including replacement of the treatment works shall be established by ordinance. 
(Ord. 375 § 7-2, 1983) 
13.44.030 - Basis of user fee-Fee structure. 
    All users within the city's service area shall be assessed a monthly sewer user rate consisting of a customer service charge and a volume charge. 
A.  The customer service charge shall be assessed to recover costs that apply equally to each user of the system regardless of volume contribution. It shall be billed on a customer account basis. 
B.  The volume charge shall be the amount charged a customer for the quantity of wastewater contributed to the city's system during a billing period. 
1.  For the single-family residential and multifamily residential users, this fee shall be based on the average water used by that user during the winter quarter (December, January and February) as measured at the dwelling by the city water meter. A single-family residential and multifamily residential user may submit a written request to the city administrator or designated representative to use alternate months for the averaging period. The city administrator or designated representative is authorized to substitute different month of a calendar year to obtain a three (3) month averaging period to calculate the annual sewer average for the user and adjust the sewer user fee accordingly. The following situations may be considered by the city administrator or designated representative to select an alternate month to be used for the recalculation of the sewer user fee: weather conditions, shut-off of service, new ownership, irrigation, or leaks within the user's dwelling. The city administrator or designated representative may utilize the prior year's average when a three (3) month averaging period cannot be determined due to the situations noted herein. 
2.  For single-family residential users not having a winter water consumption history, their sewer bill for the first month of service and every month thereafter shall be based on the number of reported occupants times two thousand (2,000) gallons per occupant per month with a minimum implied water usage of two thousand (2,000) gallons per month. After a period of three (3) full months as measured at the dwelling by the city water meter, a single-family residential user may submit a written request to the city administrator or designated representative for a review of the average sewer consumption used by the user. The city administrator or designated representative will calculate the annual sewer average based on this period of three (3) full months and adjust the sewer user fee accordingly. For multifamily residential users not having a winter water consumption history, the sewer average shall be based on the previous owner's average. When a previous owner's average is not available due to new construction or shut off of services the sewer average shall be based on the number of reported occupants for all units times two thousand (2,000) gallons per occupant with a minimum implied water usage of two thousand (2,000) gallons per unit per month. Otherwise, the assigned average monthly water consumption will be used until such time as a winter quarter water consumption history is obtained for the individual user. 
3.  For residential users who purchase and move to another property within the city, the established volume charge will be transferred to the new property. 
C.  Charges shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the following schedule: 
1. Residential - Single family - Multifamily customer service charge, $ per account $3.48 Volume charge, $ per 1,000 gallons or any portion thereof (based on winter quarter average) $6.13 2. Commercial customer service charge, $ per account, per month $3.48 Volume charge, $ per 1,000 gallons or any portion thereof (based on monthly water usage) $6.13  
(Rates are current as of July 1, 2017, and are subject to modification by resolution pursuant to subsection D.) 
D.  The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
E.  A resolution shall be presented for governing body action to ratify said adjustments. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
(Ord. 836 (part), 2008; Ord. 828 (part), 2008; Ord. 814, 2008; Ord. 707 (part), 2003; Ord. 631 (part), 2001; Ord. 594, 1998; Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 514 (part), 1992; Ord. 482, 1990; Ord. 481 (part), 1990; Ord. 479, 1989; Ord. 437, 1985; Ord. 427, 1984; Ord. 375 § 7-3, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 904, § 4, 7-25-2011; Ord. No. 940, § 1, 10-14-2013; Res. No. 1871, § 3, 6-22-2015 ; Res. No. 1908, § 3, 6-27-2016 ; Res. No. 1939 , § 3, 6-26-2017) 
13.44.035 - Fee structure for users not served by city water system. 
A.  Any commercial user served by the wastewater system of the city who is not served by the water system of the city shall install a city-approved water meter on the user's private well(s). 
1.  This meter shall be installed prior to connection to city wastewater system except as provided in subsection B of this section. The owner of the property upon which an approved water meter is located shall assure that such meter is at all times in good working order, and shall contact the utility department director to cause the meter to be repaired or replaced. The property owner shall bear all costs of meter installation and repair or replacement. For additional provisions concerning water meter installation and property owner responsibilities, see Chapter 13.04. 
2.  Such meter shall be read on a monthly basis to determine volume charge for the purpose of billing for wastewater contribution to the city's system. The fee structure shall be in accordance with Section 13.44.030 of this code. 
B.  Any residential user served by the wastewater system of the city who is not served by the water system of the city shall be charged a monthly volume charge based upon the city-wide average residential water consumption of the winter quarter. This volume rate will be adjusted annually in conjunction with the annual sewer rate calculation for residential users served by the city water system. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008; Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 526 (part), 1994) 
13.44.040 - Surcharge for excess BOD or suspended solids. 
A.  For those contributors who contribute wastewater, the strength of which is greater than the upper limit of normal domestic sewage, a surcharge in addition to the normal charge will be collected. This surcharge shall be determined by the town based on estimates of treatment costs of excess BOD and SS concentrations at the time such contributors are connected to the town's wastewater treatment system. 
B.  Any user which discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge from the town's treatment works, or any user which discharges any substance which singly or by interaction with other substances causes identifiable increases in the cost of operation, maintenance or replacement of the treatment works, shall pay for such increased costs. The strength of effluent shall be determined by the responsible plant operating personnel and users shall be charged the additional surcharge rates as provided by ordinance. 
(Ord. 375 § 7-4, 1983) 
13.44.045 - Septic waste disposal facility user fees. 
    User fees for septic waste disposal shall be based on the estimated operation and maintenance costs for the septic waste disposal facility and shall be established by resolution of the city council. Such fees shall be reviewed annually to assure equity of the system and to assure that sufficient funds will be collected from the system to adequately operate and maintain the septic waste disposal facility. Failure to conduct the annual review shall be grounds for the initiation of a current review process only and shall not invalidate existing fee schedules which shall remain in effect until modified by affirmative council action. 
(Ord. 518 § 12, 1993) 
13.44.050 - Sewer plant investment fees-Amount-Responsibility. 
A.  All charges for connection to the city's wastewater system made pursuant hereto shall be paid by the owner of the property, developer or contractor and shall be paid to the city upon issuance of the tap permit. A right-of-way permit will be required for excavation onto city right-of-way or other public land. 
B.  The plant investment fee for connections to the city wastewater system shall be determined by the following schedule. This fee does not include the cost to excavate and install the tap to the main and the service line to the property including excavation and surface restoration charges. 
Water Meter or Service Size Unit Capacity Value Fee per Capacity Unit Plant Investment Fee 3/4 in. or 1 in. connection 1.0 $1,000.00 $1,000.00 11/2 in. connection 2.0  1,000.00  2,000.00 2 in. connection 3.2  1,000.00  3,200.00 3 in. connection 6.0  1,000.00  6,000.00 4 in. connection 11.0  1,000.00 11,000.00  
(Rates are current as of August 21, 2008, and are subject to modification by resolution pursuant to subsection (D) below.) 
    For any sanitary sewer connection over four (4) inches, the wastewater plant investment fee shall be negotiated by the city administrator according to existing conditions at the time of the request for such connection. 
C.  Any property served by the city outside the corporate limits shall be charged one and one-half (1.5) times the total plant investment fees indicated in this section. 
D.  The rates and charges established in this section may be modified by a resolution adopted and ratified by the governing body. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
E.  A resolution shall be presented for governing body action to ratify said adjustments. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
(Ord. 836 (part), 2008; Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 375 § 7-5, 1983) 
(Ord. No. 904, § 5, 7-25-2011) 
13.44.070 - Replacement account. 
    The city will establish and maintain a funded replacement reserve throughout the useful life of the wastewater collection and treatment works. One hundred percent (100%) of the estimated annual depreciation expense per year shall be credited to this reserve until a total of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) is accumulated. This account may be used for replacement or repairs necessary to assure the collection and treatment works reaching their useful life. In the event any portion of the fund is used, deposits shall be resumed to maintain the balance of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 449, 1986: Ord. 375 § 7-7, 1983) 
Chapter 13.48 - BILLING-CALL-OUT FEES-RIGHT TO DISCONTINUE SERVICE 

13.48.010 - Billing status. 
    It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the city of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing requirements. The application for service or for change of name or billing shall be made upon the appropriate forms available at City Hall. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 375 § 8-1, 1983) 
13.48.020 - Vacant units. 
    Vacant units will not be charged for sewer service if the water service is discontinued by the city and the city has been properly informed in writing that a unit is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days. After notification of discontinuance, the water at the residence shall be shut off at the curb. 
(Ord. 576 (part), 1997: Ord. 481 (part), 1990: Ord. 375 § 8-2, 1983) 
13.48.030 - Monthly billing dates and delinquent account. 
A.  Property owner shall be responsible for payment of all utility bills unless property owner assigns tenant responsibility for payment of such bills. Such assignment shall be in writing. All utility bills shall be sent to the property owner or tenant on a monthly basis. All monthly charges for wastewater services shall be due and payable on the twentieth of each month. If payment is not made by the twentieth of the month, the account shall be deemed delinquent. If payment is not received within thirty (30) days after initial billing, a letter shall be sent to the owner and tenant at the mailing address(es) on file. The letter shall state: 
1.  That the account is delinquent; 
2.  That if the account is not paid in full on or before sixty (60) days after the initial billing (giving the date of the sixtieth day), the account shall be deemed in default and services discontinued; and 
3.  That the bill may be contested or challenged by contacting the city finance office (giving address and telephone number) prior to the fiftieth day after initial billing (giving the date of the fiftieth day). If payment of the account in full is not received or if the account is not settled within sixty (60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in default and services discontinued. 
B.  Any residential, or commercial, property owner or tenant who has had service discontinued for nonpayment of utility charges shall pay the bill in its entirety for all utility charges including water, sewer, garbage, landfill, pest control, etc., and shall deposit with the city a sum equivalent to two (2) times the average monthly bill for all municipal utility services for that property prior to service being restored. 
C.  Users served by the city water system shall have water shutoff for nonpayment of utility charges. At the time of turn-on of service, the property owner shall be assessed the applicable fees and deposit as specified in Sections 13.12.040 and 13.12.070. 
D.  Users not served by the city water system shall be subject to discontinuance of service by capping of their wastewater service line by the utility department. Such discontinuance shall require the express authorization of the city administrator prior to capping. If services are restored during regular working hours of utility department staff, the turn-on fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) if wastewater service has been capped. If services are restored during other than regular working hours, the turn-on fee shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) if wastewater service has been capped. At the time of turn-on of service, the property owner shall be assessed the deposit as specified in Section 13.12.070. 
E.  The deposit shall be held for a period of one (1) year. If the property owner or tenant demonstrates good faith in payment of bills in a timely fashion, the deposit shall be returned. 
F.  If the property owner or tenant cannot demonstrate good faith in payment of bills, the deposit shall be held by the city until such time of final billing. Final billing shall be made and deducted from moneys on deposit and any balance returned to the property owner or tenant. The property owner or tenant shall be responsible for the payment of the final bill in total if the deposit does not fully satisfy the debt to the city. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 692, 2003; Ord. 576 (part), 1997; Ord. 526 (part), 1994; Ord. 423, 1984; Ord. 375 § 8-3, 1983) 
13.48.045 - Improper wastewater use. 
A.  Any person who discharges wastewater into the city's wastewater system without first having established an account shall pay the city a flat monthly rate based on the average monthly volume contributed for that customer class for the number of months person has so discharged. In addition, it shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly discharge wastewater into the city's wastewater system without first having established an account. A violation of this subsection shall result in a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such unlawful usage of city wastewater system. 
B.  The city administrator shall be authorized to direct that sewer service line serving such premises is capped until any past charges, fees and/or penalties are paid. 
(Ord. 526 (part), 1994) 
13.48.050 - Utility call-out fees. 
    The city shall assess a call-out fee for emergency service rendered after hours, on weekends or holidays. The amount of the call-out fee shall be established by resolution of the city council and shall take into account the cost of prevailing wages for utility department employees together with the appropriate benefit calculation. Billing to person requesting said call-out shall be made by finance department upon receipt of billing information from public utility department. Such fees shall be reviewed and revised as necessary on an annual basis. Failure to conduct the annual review shall be grounds for the initiation of a current review process only and shall not invalidate existing fee schedules which shall remain in effect until modified by affirmative council action. 
(Ord. 518 § 13, 1993) 
Division III. - Sanitation Collection and Solid Waste Disposal Facility* 
* Prior ordinance history: Ords. 649, 631, 625, 576, 447, 435 and 389. 
Chapter 13.52 - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS AND INFORMATION 

13.52.010 - Duties of governing body. 
    Subject to the laws relating to public utilities, the governing body shall fix all rates for sanitation and solid waste facility services within and outside the corporate limits of the city and make regulations for the collection of the fees and charges. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.52.020 - Powers and duties of city administrator. 
    The city administrator, or his/her authorized representative, shall enforce all necessary rules, regulations and penalties to enforce the collection of fees and for the protection of the city's property and rights pertaining to the city's sanitation collection and solid waste disposal system. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.52.030 - Responsibilities of public works department director. 
    The public works director shall be responsible for the management and direction of the city's sanitation and solid waste collection and disposal system and for the operation of the municipal solid waste disposal facilities. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.52.040 - Definitions. 
A.  "Construction/demolition waste" includes but is not limited to stone, wood, concrete, asphaltic concrete, cinder blocks, plaster and metal. 
B.  "Debris" means discarded automobile parts, household appliances, furniture, construction materials, dead animals, or any other materials too large to be disposed of in a standard solid waste container, or which may be inappropriate for deposit in a regular solid waste disposal pit. 
C.  "Hazardous waste" means any waste or combination of wastes which pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment, as defined as hazardous wastes in Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality Hazardous Waste Rules and Regulations, Chapter 2, Identification and Listing of Hazardous Waste. 
D.  "Recyclable materials" means paper products, aluminum, glass, plastics, metal cans, or newspapers which can be diverted from the waste stream. 
E.  "Scavenging" means the unauthorized removal of solid waste or debris from the landfill site after it has been collected and deposited in accordance with Division III of this title. 
F.  "Solid waste" means any and all kitchen refuse, waste food, offal or animal matter, or anything else whatsoever which may decompose and become offensive, unsanitary or dangerous to health; or any other refuse such as paper products, cans, bottles, or other waste materials which may be safely and conveniently disposed of in a standard solid waste container. 
G.  "Yard waste" means leaves or grass clippings suitable for composting. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004; Ord. No. 984 , § 1, 8-22-2016) 
13.52.050 - Collection-Intervals. 
    All solid waste shall be collected and disposed of, by employees of the city, and at regular intervals as prescribed in Section 13.56.070, Collection of solid waste is subject to restrictions as per Section 13.56.060. No person, except the employees of the city or persons under contract with the city for such purposes shall collect and transport any solid waste from city-owned containers. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.52.060 - Damaging solid waste containers. 
    No person shall in any manner tamper with, deface or destroy any solid waste container belonging to the city. Any person found guilty of these acts shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such container damaged. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.56 - CONTAINERS-COLLECTION 

13.56.010 - Containers required-Specifications. 
A.  Every owner or occupant of any occupied premises within the city shall obtain and utilize solid waste containers provided by the city. One (1) one-hundred (100) gallon roll-out will be provided to residential users in areas without alleys. One and one-half (1 1/2) yard or three (3) yard dumpsters will be used in residential areas with alleys. One and one-half (1 1/2) yard dumpsters are designed to be shared by two (2) residences, three (3) yard dumpsters by four (4) residences. 
B.  Residential users who desire more than the allocated container capacity may request additional roll-out dumpsters as appropriate. Charges for additional containers shall be as in Section 13.64.030. 
C.  The city shall provide dumpster capacity as is necessary to accommodate commercial premises at such collection intervals as are established for such premises. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.56.030 - Ownership of containers. 
    The city shall provide roll-out containers or dumpsters for all premises served by the city's sanitation collection system. Such containers or dumpsters shall be provided to all users within the corporate limits of the city. All dumpsters and roll-out containers remain the property of the city. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.56.040 - Responsibility of owner to maintain container. 
    It shall be the duty of every user of the city's sanitation collection system to maintain the roll-out container or dumpster in good order and to notify the public works department of necessary repairs. The public works department will repair or replace containers or dumpsters as needed. Costs of repair, if necessary due to negligence or willful destruction on the part of the user, shall be itemized and charged to the user as an additional cost of service. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.56.050 - Use of containers-Collection generally. 
A.  It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of any premises within the city limits to deposit in the appropriate container all solid waste produced at or brought into any such premise. 
B.  All solid waste must be in paper or plastic bags, tied securely, and placed in the container. No container shall be allowed to overflow so that solid waste may be blown or scattered about in any way. 
C.  No debris or excessively heavy yard waste shall be placed in any dumpster or roll-out container, as such materials can damage container and/or mechanical parts of the sanitation truck. For regulations concerning removal of debris, see Section 13.60.020. 
D.  Users of the city's sanitation system are required to separate yard waste and are encouraged to separate recyclable materials out of the solid waste deposited into city containers and place same in receptacles specifically designed for such use. 
E.  No person shall deposit any solid waste or other debris in another's solid waste container unless the consent of the property owner or occupant of the premises is first obtained. Yard waste shall not be permitted in any containers other than those designated for such use. Solid waste containers located on public property are designed for visitors and specific users of such public property and are not designed for the regular deposit of solid waste by non-city residents. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004; Ord. No. 984 , § 2, 8-22-2016) 
13.56.060 - Placement of containers. 
A.  Dumpsters shall be located in alleys at positions determined by the public works department to facilitate ease of route flow. 
B.  Dumpsters on commercial property parking lots shall be placed in a three (3) sided enclosure to screen the dumpster from public view. Plans for the enclosure shall be approved by the public works director and are the responsibility of the developer to install and maintain to city specifications. 
C.  Roll-out containers shall be placed in the gutter in front of the residence by seven (7:00) a.m. on the designated collection day. No person shall place the roll-out in the street prior to one (1) calendar day before the collection of the solid waste, nor shall any person leave the roll-out in the street more than twenty-four (24) hours after collection. 
D.  No vehicle shall be parked so as to obstruct access by sanitation collection crews to any dumpster or roll-out. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.56.070 - Frequency of collection. 
A.  Residential. The collection of solid waste in residential areas shall be made once a week according to route schedules determined by the public works director. 
B.  Commercial. The collection of solid waste for commercial properties shall be made daily or at other reasonable intervals as requested. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.56.080 - Collection services outside the city limits. 
A.  Collection outside the city limits may be requested. Allowance of the collection shall be at the discretion of the public works director, taking into consideration such factors as proximity to city limits, access to property and service to other property in the area to be served. 
B.  Users outside the corporate limits of the city shall be charged the monthly rates set forth in Section 13.64.030(A) with the exception of the volume charge, which shall be double those set forth in the fee schedule. 
(Ord. 737, 2004: Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.60 - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY OPERATION- DEBRIS ACCUMULATION AND REMOVAL 

13.60.010 - Accumulation of solid waste or debris unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning or occupying a lot or premises, or for that person's agent, to permit or cause the accumulation of solid waste or debris upon the lot or premises, including that property up to the center line of any alley bordering property. Such accumulation has been declared a nuisance pursuant to Section 8.20.110. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.60.020 - Responsibility for removal. 
    Removal of debris or solid waste that does not fit in designated solid waste containers, shall be the responsibility of the property owner or occupant. Such debris or solid waste shall be removed and dumped in an approved solid waste disposal facility. If material is left outside of containers (dumpsters or roll-outs) which must be manually placed in the sanitation truck, the owner of the property may be assessed an additional cleanup fee for manpower and equipment time at the rate set forth in Section 13.64.030. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004; Ord. No. 984 , § 3, 8-22-2016) 
13.60.030 - Solid waste disposal facility regulations. 
A.  Individuals using the city solid waste facility shall observe all regulations of that facility. 
B.  All material deposited in the solid waste facility must be in the designated pit. It is unlawful to dump solid waste or debris outside the solid waste facility or in any location within the solid waste facility that has not been designated for such dumping. 
C.  It is unlawful to dispose of any hazardous waste (as defined in Section 13.52.040(C)) within the solid waste facility. 
D.  All loads are subject to inspection by designated city officials in accordance with state and federal regulations. 
E.  The public works director is authorized to temporarily suspend operations at the solid waste disposal facility due to high wind or muddy conditions that make daily operation difficult. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.60.035 - Transporting of solid waste or debris. 
    To prevent scattering of solid waste and debris, all persons transporting solid waste, debris or recyclable materials to the solid waste facility or any recycling location must cover the load with a tarp, wire mesh or some other means which prevents the material from blowing or falling out of the vehicle. Any person traveling to the solid waste facility without meeting the provisions of this section may be assessed a fee as set forth in Section 13.64.030 in addition to any other fees assessed. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004; Ord. No. 984 , § 4, 8-22-2016) 
13.60.040 - Scavenging unlawful-Solid waste property of city. 
    All solid waste or debris becomes the property of the city when it is deposited in the solid waste facility. No scavenging shall be permitted by any person. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.64 - USER CHARGE SYSTEM 

13.64.010 - Generation of revenue. 
    The user charge system shall generate adequate revenues to pay all costs of operation and maintenance, as determined by generally accepted accounting principles, including equipment replacement and capital improvements. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.64.020 - Billing status. 
    It is the responsibility of each property owner or tenant to notify the city of intent to change name, discontinue, begin or in any way alter billing requirements. Application forms to obtain, modify or discontinue a service account shall be available at City Hall. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 714 (part), 2004)

A.  All users of the city's sanitation collection and solid waste disposal system shall be assessed a monthly rate on a customer account basis according to the following fee schedule:

The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised by any subsequent resolution. The governing body may further review and adjust such charges during the budgetary process as is necessary in order to meet the anticipated expenditures of the department. The rates so determined shall remain in effect until or unless revised in any subsequent year. 
E.  The city may establish special handling fees at the solid waste facility to cover special circumstances such as large construction or demolition loads, tires, dead animals or hazardous materials that impact the daily operation method and operational life of the facility. Such disposal shall be allowed according to the conditions of the operating regulations of the facility. Fee structures for such special charges shall be established from time to time by resolution. 
(Ord. 836 (part), 2008: Ord. 828 (part), 2008; Ord. 805, 2007: Ord. 776 (part), 2006; Ord. 740, 2004; Ord. 724, 2004; Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
(Ord. No. 856, 7-13-2009; Ord. No. 891, §§ 1, 2, 6-28-2010; Res. No. 1676, 8-23-2010; Ord. No. 904, § 7, 7-25-2011; Res. No. 1871, § 4, 6-22-2015 ; Res. No. 1908, § 4, 6-27-2016 ; Res. No. 1939 , § 3, 6-26-2017) 
13.64.040 - Replacement account-Sanitation collection division. 
    The city will establish and maintain a replacement account for the sanitation collection division of the department. One hundred percent (100%) of the estimated annual depreciation expense per year shall be credited to this reserve until a total of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) is accumulated. This account may be used for replacement or repairs necessary to the division's operation. In the event any portion of the fund is used, deposits shall be resumed to maintain the balance designated. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.64.045 - Replacement accounts-Solid waste disposal facility division. 
    The city will establish and maintain replacement accounts for the solid waste disposal facility for equipment replacement, capital improvements and post-closure liability. One hundred percent (100%) of the estimated annual depreciation expense per year shall be credited to the equipment and capital improvement reserves until a total of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) is accumulated. These accounts may be used for replacement or repairs necessary to the division's operation. In the event any portion of the fund is used, deposits shall be resumed to maintain the balances designated. Post-closure reserve levels shall be based on generally accepted accounting practices for determination of post-closure liability. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.64.050 - Vacant units. 
    Vacant units will not be charged for sanitation collection or solid waste disposal service if the water service is discontinued by the city and the unit is or will be vacant for a period of at least thirty (30) days and the city has been informed in writing that such unit is vacant. After notification of discontinuance, the water at the residence shall be shut off at the curb and the solid waste collection receptacle removed, if applicable. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.64.060 - Monthly billing dates and delinquent accounts. 
A.  All utility bills shall be sent to the property owner or tenant on a monthly basis. All monthly charges for solid waste shall be due and payable on the twentieth of each month. If payment is not made by the twentieth of the month, the account shall be deemed delinquent. If payment is not received within sixty (60) days after initial billing, the account shall be deemed in default. Accounts in default shall be subject to the provisions of Section 13.12.070. 
B.  Commercial haulers, contractors and other frequent users of the solid waste disposal facility may establish a billing account with the city upon application and approval by the city finance department. Billing terms as designated in subsection A of this section shall apply to such users. 
(Ord. 828 (part), 2008: Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 13.68 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

13.68.010 - Regulations promulgated by governing body-Enforcement. 
    The governing body at its discretion may establish additional rules and regulations for sanitation collection, solid waste disposal and hours of operation for the landfill. Division III of this title shall be enforced by the police department under the direction of the city administrator. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
13.68.020 - Penalties. 
    Any person guilty of violating any provision of this division shall be subject to a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for such offense. 
(Ord. 714 (part), 2004) 
Division IV. - Communication Systems 
Chapter 13.72 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS CABLE SYSTEM 

13.72.010 - Establishment. 
    The city creates the city municipal telecommunications cable system (MTCS) under the direct control of the governing body of Douglas, including management, operation, maintenance, extension, improvement and monthly service charges necessary to produce net revenue sufficient to pay outstanding debts of MTCS and interest on such debt, and to accumulate any required revenue funds as necessary. 
(Ord. 484 § 1, 1990) 
13.72.020 - Franchise requirements. 
A.  The city awards a nonexclusive franchise to the city municipal telecommunications cable system (MTCS) for a term of fifteen (15) years for the purpose of construction of a telecommunications cable system. 
B.  The MTCS will pay the city general fund a three percent (3%) franchise fee of gross revenues for the privilege of utilizing the public rights-of-way in the city. 
C.  The MTCS shall at all times use ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisances to the public. The MTCS will construct and operate the system and related facilities in accordance with all generally accepted related industry codes, standards and recommendations that are applicable. 
D.  The city reserves the right to increase both the franchise fee rate and the revenue on which such fee is based so as to increase franchise payments, in accordance with applicable federal law. 
E.  The MTCS will make and enforce all such proper rules as to collection of delinquent bills and as to discontinuance of any service to delinquent customers as it may, in its opinion, deem necessary. 
F.  The rates charged for cable television/radio service shall be set by the MTCS. Such rates will provide adequate revenues to cover the costs of operation and maintenance, debt service, plant expansion and necessary and reasonable fund surpluses and reserves. 
G.  The provisions of this franchise shall be accepted in writing by the MTCS. 
(Ord. 484 § 2, 1990) 
13.72.030 - Services to be provided. 
    The MTCS, acting under authority granted in Sections 13.72.010 and 13.72.020 of this chapter, will establish a schedule of services to be provided. For example: the number of channels, radio service, security, meter reading, and implement same at their discretion. 
(Ord. 484 § 3, 1990) 
13.72.040 - Financing. 
    The MTCS shall obtain its initial financing through general fund appropriations or the issuance of municipal bonds as determined by the city council, provided that the rate structure adopted shall provide for the retirement of said bonds or the repayment of appropriated amounts to the general fund. MTCS shall be accounted for as an enterprise fund. 
(Ord. 484 § 4, 1990) 
13.72.050 - Citizens advisory committee. 
A.  There is created a cable citizens advisory committee (committee) for the purpose of reviewing and recommending programming and services to be available to the subscribers of the MTCS. 
B.  The members of the committee will be selected as follows: 
1.  The mayor of the city shall serve as its chairman with no voting right except to break a tie vote; 
2.  The city clerk or a member of his/her staff so designated by him/her shall serve as secretary of the committee with no voting right; 
3.  One (1) member of the committee will be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council; 
4.  One (1) member of the committee shall be selected by the Board of Education of Converse County School District No. 1; 
5.  Three (3) members shall be elected at each regular municipal election as members at large to serve for a term of two years each. 
C.  The term of the members of the committee shall be as follows: 
1.  The term of the mayor will run concurrently with his/her term in office; 
2.  The term of the city clerk or designee will run as long as he/she shall hold such position; 
3.  The term of the member appointed by the city mayor and approved by council shall run concurrently with the term of the mayor by whom he/she was appointed; 
4.  The terms of the members selected by the school board and the elected members shall be for a period of two (2) years or until their successors are duly elected and qualified. 
D.  The committee shall meet no less than two (2) times each year. Meetings shall be upon call of the chairman or by written request of three (3) or more members of the committee. The committee shall be conducted according to Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. 484 § 5, 1990) 
Title 15 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
DIVISION I. - BUILDING CODES 
Chapter 15.04 - ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES 

15.04.010 - Building permits, fees and exemptions. 
A.  Before receiving a building permit for a structure in the city, the owner or his/her agent shall meet the requirements of the building official as set forth by the building and municipal codes and pay the following fees based on valuation of the project: 
Up to $2,000 $25.00 $2,001-$25,000 $25.00 first $2,000 and $7.00 each additional $1,000 up to $25,000 $25,001-$50,000 $186.00 first $25,000 and $5.00 each additional $1,000 up to $50,000 $50,001-$100,000 $311.00 first $50,000 and $3.00 each additional $1,000 up to $100,000 $100,001-$500,000 $461.00 first $100,000 and $2.00 each additional $1,000 up to $500,000 $500,001-$1,000,000 $1,251.00 first $500,000 and $1.50 each additional $1,000 up to $1,000,000 $1,000,001 and up $2,001.00 first $1,000,000 and $1.00 each additional $1,000 after that  
    Permit fees for water heater replacements, plumbing fixture replacements, sprinkler systems installations, water and sewer or gas pipe repair, electrical outlet and switch relocates that require only one (1) inspection will be reduced to a ten dollar ($10.00) permit fee. 
B.  The city may also charge a plan review fee for projects that require a plan review of construction drawings. The plan review fee of sixty-five percent (65%) of the building permit fee is the standard charge. If the plans are being reviewed by the State Fire Marshal's Office, for fire and life safety, the charge for plan review fee from the city may be reduced to twenty-five percent (25%) of the building permit fee. 
C.  The city, county, state or the United States shall be exempt from paying the fee for a building permit, but such permit shall be required for the contractor and he/she shall comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
D.  Water and sewer tap fees shall be paid no later than the time of scheduling of the final inspection. 
E.  Exemptions. Exemptions from the building permit requirement shall be those listed in the permits section of the current building code as adopted by the city, along with the following stipulations: 
1.  One (1) story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the roof area does not exceed two hundred (200) square feet and the structure is constructed on a nonpermanent foundation. This exemption from the permit requirement does not exempt the structure from building code requirements. 
2.  Accessory structures larger than two hundred (200) square feet, and/or accessory structures of any size constructed on permanent foundations or concrete slabs, shall be subject to building permit requirements, construction code requirements and the setback requirements for the occupied zoning classification. 
F.  Timing and Duration of Permits. Building permits shall be issued for a period not to exceed three hundred sixty-five (365) days or twelve (12) months. Building permits may be extended for a period of up to one hundred eighty (180) days at the request of the permit holder, with concurrence of the building official. An extension fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged for an extension. If more than five hundred forty-five (545) days have elapsed, the original and extended permits shall be null and void, and a completely new application with appropriate fees shall be required. 
Where a project has achieved vertical construction, the project shall be fully enclosed and exterior finishes applied within three hundred sixty-five (365) calendar days, without exception. Failure to comply with this provision shall result in citations as provided for in subsection B of Section 15.04.050. until such time as the project exterior is completed. 
(Ord. 813 (part), 2008: Ord. 706, 2003: Ord. 671, 2003: prior code § 6-6) 
(Ord. No. 896, § 1, 5-23-2011) 
15.04.020 - Notification and inspection of building construction. 
    The building official shall be notified by the holder of a permit under this title. The building official shall inspect the building as required by the current construction codes adopted by the city, and any other time indicated by the building official as necessary for proper code compliance. If work is not complete or open for inspection and an additional inspection is required, the building official may charge a reinspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be paid prior to calling for the next inspection. 
(Ord. 722 (part), 2004: Ord. 671, 2003: Ord. 505 § 1, 1992: prior code § 6-7) 
15.04.030 - Structures encroaching on street or alley. 
A.  Any structure encroaching on any city street or alley, which structure was in existence prior to January 1, 1978, shall be permitted to continue to use that portion of any street or alley which it is on, unless modified or improved subsequent to January 1, 1978. 
B.  If any structure encroaching on any city street or alley is modified, improved in any way or expanded such structure shall be removed from any portion of any street or alley it is on and in addition such structure shall be required to meet all zoning and setback requirements in existence at the time of such modification. 
(Ord. 249 §§ 1, 2, 1978) 
15.04.050 - Building official. 
A.  Responsibilities. The building official shall be responsible for all inspections, enforcement actions, administrative duties and responsibilities for enforcement and administration of all building codes and permits required under this title. 
B.  The building official is authorized to issue citations to appear in the Douglas Municipal Court to any person deemed to be in violation of the provisions of this title. 
(Ord. 722 (part), 2004: Ord. 505 § 3, 1992) 
15.04.060 - Certificate of occupancy. 
A.  Definition: 
    "Certificate of Occupancy" (C of O) means the key document used to certify the legal use and occupancy of a building. The document is issued by the planning and community development department and describes how a building may be occupied, i.e. a two-family home, a parking lot, a forty (40) unit multiple dwelling, or a store. 
B.  If planned construction is creating a new building or will result in a change of use, egress, or occupancy to an existing building, a new or amended certificate of occupancy is necessary. The contractor's or owner's representative shall contact the planning and community development department to arrange for the necessary construction, plumbing, electrical, and elevator inspections. 
C.  The certificate of occupancy will be authorized by the building official when the completed work complies with the submitted plans and applicable laws, all paperwork is completed, all necessary approvals have been obtained from other appropriate city agencies, all fees owed to the department are paid, and all relevant violations are resolved. A new building cannot be legally occupied until a certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
D.  A temporary certificate of occupancy (TCO) may be authorized by the building official and issued by the community development department if all work is substantially completed on a construction project requiring a certificate of occupancy (CO), with the stipulation that all unfinished work noted on the TCO must be completed within the period specified. Said period will be determined at the discretion of the building official with the concurrence of community development director, and will be of a duration not exceeding one (1) year from the date of issuance. Neither a TCO or a CO will be issued until the building owner and/or contractor submits a copy of the electrical wiring permit for any electrical work as required by Wyoming State Statutes along with copies of the electrical rough-in inspection report, final inspection report and any re-inspection reports from the Wyoming Department of Fire Prevention and Electrical Safety's electrical inspector. Due caution shall be exercised to preserve bench marks, control points, reference points and property corners. At the time of final inspection neither a TCO nor a CO will be issued until verification is obtained that all bench marks, control points, reference points and property corners are still properly monumented by a surveyor licensed by the state of Wyoming. 
(Ord. No. 874, 2-22-2010; Ord. No. 896, § 2, 5-23-2011; Ord. No. 956, § 2, 9-8-2014 ; Ord. No. 967, § 36, 8-10-2015 ) 
15.04.070 - Key boxes. 
    The installation of key boxes for all commercial occupancies is not mandatory but is voluntary, to allow the Douglas Fire Department emergency entry. When installed the key box shall be located within ten (10) feet of the front door, a minimum of six (6) feet above the ground level and as approved by the fire department. Applications to order the key box shall be obtained from the fire department. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 3, 9-8-2014 ) 
15.04.080 - Climatic and geographic design criteria. 
    Buildings, dwellings, townhouses, structures, and portions thereof, including patio covers and accessory buildings, shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the following climatic and geographic design criteria: 
Ground and Roof Snow Load = 30 pounds per square foot plus snow drifting. 
Ultimate Design Wind Speed = 115 miles per hour (for Risk Category II). 
Basic Wind Speed = 90 miles per hour, 3 second gust, (for one- and two-family dwellings). 
Wind Exposure Category = C. 
Seismic Design Category = B (for Risk category I, II and III). 
Weathering = Severe. 
Frost Line Depth = 42 inches, minimum to bottom of footings. 
Termite Protection = Slight to Moderate. 
Heating Design Temperature = -13°F. 
Heating Degree Days = 7,343. 
Cooling Degree Days = 2,082. 
Cooling Design Temperature = 89°F, dry bulb. 
Cooling Design Temperature = 58°F, wet bulb. 
Mean Annual Temperature = 45.5°F. 
Air-Freezing Index = 2,000°F-days. 
Flood Hazard = FIRM Community Number 560013 1394 D. 
Annual Precipitation = 14 inches. 
Rainfall Intensity = 2 inches per hour. 
Hail Exposure = Slight. 
Climate Zone/Moisture Designation = 6B. 
Longitude = 105°23'. 
Latitude = 42°46'. 
Elevation above Sea Level = 4,815 feet. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 4, 9-8-2014 ) 
15.04.090 - Violation penalties. 
A.  Any person in violation of Title 15 shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each separate offense. Every twenty-four (24) hour period, after the time specified in the written notice, in which the violation is not corrected or abated shall be an additional offense and subject to the same penalty. Any exception will be considered and decided on a case by case basis at the discretion of the director of planning and community development. 
B.  Any person who commences any work before obtaining the necessary permit(s) may be subject to an investigation fee as determined by the planning and community development director. The investigation fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) or equal to twice the permit fee, whichever is greater. In addition, the applicant shall pay twice the amount of the permit fees to obtain the permit(s). 
( Ord. No. 956, § 5, 9-8-2014 ) 
Chapter 15.09 - UNIFORM CODE FOR THE ABATEMENT OF DANGEROUS BUILDINGS 

15.09.010 - Adopted. 
    "The 1997 Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings" published by the International Code Council, being the latest edition, is adopted by the city council. This code is adopted for the purpose of providing a just, equitable and practical method, to be cumulative with and in addition to any other remedy provided by the International Building Code, International Residential Code or otherwise available by law, whereby buildings or structures which from any cause endanger the life, limb, health, morals, property, safety or welfare of the general public or their occupants may be required to be repaired, vacated or demolished. Three (3) copies of such code shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. 513, 1992) 
(Ord. No. 895, § 2, 9-27-2010) 
15.09.020 - Penalty for noncompliance. 
    It is unlawful for any person to fail to comply with an order issued under the 1997 Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Building[s] to abate a dangerous condition and shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. A violator shall be assessed a fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). In addition to the fine, the court may also order the condition abated and assess any costs incurred by city to abate such condition if the condition is not abated by the violator. All fines obtained on convictions under this section shall be forwarded to the city's general fund to be utilized for costs the city incurs for abatement of nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 916, § 23, 5-14-2012) 
15.09.030 - Referenced building code and housing code. 
    All references in the 1997 Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings, to the Building Code, Uniform Building Code, Housing Code, or Uniform Housing Code shall be referenced to the appropriate sections of the current editions of the International Building Code or the International Residential Code. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 6, 9-8-2014 )

15.10.180 - Section 1804.3-Site grading. 
    Section 1804.3 is amended as follows: 
The ground immediately adjacent to the foundation shall be sloped away from the building at a slope of not less than one unit vertical in 20 units horizontal (5-percent slope) for a minimum distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) measured perpendicular to the face of the wall. If physical obstructions or lot lines prohibit 10 feet (3048 mm) of horizontal distance, a 5-percent slope shall be provided to an approved alternative method of diverting water away from the foundation. Swales used for this purpose shall be sloped a minimum of 2 percent where located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the building foundation. Impervious surfaces within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the building foundation shall be sloped a minimum of 2 percent away from the building. Surface drainage, including drainage from roof down spouts, shall be diverted to a storm sewer conveyance or other approved point of collection so as to not create a hazard. Lots shall be graded to drain surface water away from foundation walls, but not onto neighboring property.

Chapter 15.11 - INTERNATIONAL FUEL GAS CODE[3] 

Footnotes:

15.11.040 - Section 106.6.2-Fee schedule.

15.14.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, relocation, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, maintenance, removal and demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three (3) stories above grade plane in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures or appurtenances connected or attached to such dwellings and townhouses or structures, including permits and penalties within the city.

15.14.130 - Section R309.5-Fire sprinklers. 
    Section R309.5 is amended as follows: 
Private garages shall be protected by fire sprinklers where the garage wall has been designed based on Table R302.1(2), Footnote a. Sprinklers in garages shall be connected to an automatic sprinkler system that complies with Section P2904. Garage sprinklers shall be residential sprinklers or quick-response sprinklers, designed to provide a density of 0.05 gpm/ft 2 . Garage doors shall not be considered obstructions with respect to sprinkler placement. The installation of fire sprinklers in garages may be incorporated at the discretion of the owner and/or contractor and/or registered design professional. If installed, the installation shall be in conformance with this section and Section P2904 - Dwelling Unit Fire Sprinkler Systems.

The installation of fire sprinklers in one- and two-family dwellings may be incorporated at the discretion of the owner and/or contractor and/or registered design professional.     Section R315.3 is amended to read as follows:

Exceptions:

15.14.180 - Section R407.3-Structural requirements. 
    Section R407.3 is amended as follows: 
The columns shall be restrained to prevent lateral displacement at the bottom end. Wood columns shall not be less in nominal size than 4 inches by 4 inches). Steel columns shall not be less than 3-inch-diameter Schedule 40 pipe manufactured in accordance with ASTM A 53 Grade B or approved equivalent. Wood or steel columns supporting wood beams shall be attached with a metal connector to prevent rotation of the beam and column. Steel beams shall be supported by steel columns and attached with a metal connector to prevent rotation of the beam and/or column. Where required to be shimmed, wood beams bearing on concrete shall be shimmed with metal or wood shims protected against decay. Where required to be shimmed, steel beams bearing on concrete shall be shimmed with metal shims 
Exception: In Seismic Design Categories A, B and C, columns no more than 48 inches in height on a pier or footing are exempt from the bottom end lateral displacement requirement within under-floor areas enclosed by a continuous foundation. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 99, 9-8-2014 ) 
15.14.190 - Section R501.3-Fire Protection of Floors. 
    Section R501.3 is amended as follows: 
Floor assemblies, not required elsewhere in this code to be fire-resistance rated, shall be provided with a 1/2-inch (12.7 mm) gypsum wallboard membrane, ?-inch (16 mm) wood structural panel membrane, or equivalent on the underside of the floor framing member. 
Exceptions: 
1. Floor assemblies located directly over a space protected by an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section P2904, NFPA13D, or other approved equivalent sprinkler systems. 
2. Floor assemblies located directly over a crawl space not intended for storage or fuel-fired appliances. 
3. Portions of floor assemblies can be unprotected by complying with the following: 
3.1. The aggregate of the unprotected portions shall not exceed 80 square feet per story. 
3.2. Fire blocking in accordance with Section R302.11.1 shall be installed along the perimeter of the unprotected portion to separate the unprotected portion from the remainder of the floor assembly. 
4. Wood floor assemblies using dimension lumber or structural composite lumber equal to or greater than 2-inch by 10-inch (50.8 mm by 254 mm) nominal dimension, or other approved floor assemblies demonstrating equivalent fire performance. 
The installation of floor assemblies with the above regulations may be incorporated at the discretion of the owner and/or contractor and/or registered design professional. If installed, the installation shall be in conformance with this section and Section R501.3-Fire Protection of Floors. 
(Ord. No. 966 , §§ 1-3, 6-8-2015) 
15.14.200 - Table R702.3.5-Minimum thickness and application of gypsum board, footnote d. 
    Table R702.3.5, Footnote d is amended to read as follows: 
Three-eighths-inch-thick single-ply gypsum board shall not be used on a ceiling where a water-based textured finish is to be applied, or where it will be required to support insulation above a ceiling. On ceiling applications to receive a water-based texture material, either hand or spray applied, the gypsum board shall be applied perpendicular to framing. When applying a water-based texture material, the minimum gypsum board thickness shall be increased from 3/8 inch to 1/2 inch for 16-inch on center framing, and from 1/2 inch to 5/8 inch for 24-inch on center framing or 1/2-inch sag-resistant gypsum ceiling board shall be used. All ceiling applications for gypsum board with 16 inch spacing of framing members shall be a minimum thickness of 1/2 inch. All ceiling applications for gypsum board with 24 inch spacing of framing members shall be a minimum thickness of 5/8 inch. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 100, 9-8-2014 ; Ord. No. 966 , ; s; 3, 6-8-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 966 , § 3, adopted June 8, 2015, renumbered §§ 15.14.190-15.14.310 as §§ 15.14.200-15.14.320. The historical notes of said sections have been preserved for reference purposes.

Chapter 15.15 - INTERNATIONAL EXISTING BUILDING CODE 

15.15.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish rules and regulations for the repair, alteration, change of occupancy, addition and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings and detached one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses, including permits and penalties within the city. The provisions are adopted for the purposes of encouraging the continued use or reuse of legally existing buildings and structures, encouraging the historic preservation and renovation of buildings and structures having historical value, establishing life-safety requirements for all existing buildings that undergo alteration or a change in occupancy, and offering alternative methods of achieving safety so that the existing inventory of existing buildings can be preserved. 
( Ord. No. 956, § 113, 9-8-2014 )

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

1.1 - Official Title 
The official title of this document is the "Unified Land Development Code of the City of Douglas, Wyoming." For ease of use and convenience, it is referred to throughout this document as the "Unified Land Development Code" or the "Code." 
( Ord. No. 967, § 42, 8-10-2015 ) 
1.2 - Authority, Adoption, and Applicability 
1.2.1  Authority 
This Code is adopted under the powers granted and authority conferred by the laws of the State of Wyoming, including but not limited to, the following sections of the Wyoming State Statutes (W.S.): 
 §§ 9-8-101 to 9-8-302 (Land Use Planning Act) 
 §§ 15-1-401 to 15-1-422 (Annexation, Determination of Boundaries, Addition and Exclusion of Land) 
 §§ 15-1-501 to 15-1-512 (Planning - Cities and Towns) 
 §§ 15-1-601 to 15-1-611 (Zoning - Cities and Towns) 
 §§ 34-12-101 to 34-12-115 (Platting and Dedication) 
1.2.2  Adoption 
Pursuant to the powers and authority granted conferred by Wyoming State law, the City Council for the City of Douglas, Wyoming, hereby approves and adopts the provisions and regulations of this Code by ordinance, which shall be in full force and effect as of 19 August, 2015. 
1.2.3  Applicability 
The provisions and regulations of this Unified Land Development Code apply to the development of land, including the construction of buildings and other structures as well as the use of land within the incorporated boundaries of the City of Douglas, Wyoming. Pursuant to the authority granted to the City of Douglas under Wyoming law, this Code shall apply to all development whether such development is conducted by private, public, or quasi-public entities. Unless otherwise stated in this Code, these regulations shall not apply to land outside of the incorporated boundaries of the City of Douglas. 
( Ord. No. 967, § 42, 8-10-2015 ) 
1.3 - Overview and Purpose 
1.3.1  Overview 
This Code is organized into ten (10) chapters which are presented herein in a chapter-by-chapter format. Each chapter is intended to provide information pertaining to a particular phase, component, or specific consideration associated with the land development process. The chapters of this Code include: 1) General Provisions, 2) Definitions and Acronyms, 3) Application and Review Procedures, 4) Zoning, 5) General Development Standards, 6) Use-Specific Development Standards, 7) Subdivision Regulations, 8) Public Improvements and Construction, 9) Enforcement, and 10) Annexations. This Code also includes a comprehensive Table of Contents as a preface to the regulations and an Appendix, which includes resource documents that support the purpose and function of the provisions and regulations of this Code. 
1.3.2  Purpose 
This Code is adopted for the purpose of preserving and improving the public health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens and businesses of the City of Douglas, Wyoming. In particular, this Code is intended to: 
 Support and implement the goals and policies of the City of Douglas Master Plan; 
 Provide a fair and just process for reviewing and approving development by ensuring due consideration is given to protecting private property rights, the rights of individuals, and the rights of the community as a whole; 
 Ensure that appropriate opportunities to participate in the development process are provided to all concerned parties; 
 Preserve and promote predictability, consistency, and efficiency in the land development process; 
 Guide and regulate public and private interests and actions to ensure greater efficiencies in providing community infrastructure and improvements such as streets, sidewalks and other pedestrian pathways, water and wastewater services, schools, parks, recreational facilities, and other public and quasi-public facilities; 
 Establish reasonable standards for the design and layout of subdivisions and re-plats in order to further the orderly layout and use of land and to ensure proper legal descriptions and monumenting of subdivided land; 
 Ensure that public facilities and services will be available concurrent with the development of land and that such facilities and services will have sufficient capacity to serve the proposed development and that the extension of such facilities will be the requirement of the land developer rather than the current residents of the City of Douglas; and 
 Ensure that development and use of land is conducted in a manner that will prevent the pollution of air, streams, and ponds while also ensuring that all development and uses of land provide for adequate drainage management and facilities. 
( Ord. No. 967, § 42, 8-10-2015 ) 
1.4 - Instructions for Using this Code 
As identified above, this Code includes ten (10) chapters. Any person or entity proposing to initiate a land use or construct upon or otherwise develop land within the City of Douglas is encouraged to review the chapter-by-chapter summary below, which includes general instructions for using each chapter as a component of the overall Code. 
Chapter 1 - General Provisions 
This chapter memorializes adoption of the Unified Land Development Code and includes provisions establishing the authority of the City to administer and interpret the Code. The provisions of this Chapter are frequently relied upon to provide clarity and consistency in the application of the regulations of the Code. 
Chapter 2 - Definitions and Acronyms 
The terms, acronyms, and definitions in Chapter 2 are intended to provide a single comprehensive source of definitions pertaining to the use and development of land.
